text: Introduction to the Book. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and may Allah bless Muhammad. Between the years 1373 - 1378 AH, I used to hear the news of Abdul Karim Al Jarba "Abu Khawdhah" and Safouk Al Jarba, on the tongue of Muhammad bin Yahyan, may Allah have mercy on him, and some of those who come to Shaqra in Ramadan, whom my father, may Allah have mercy on him, receives. A shadow of their fragrant memories remained in my memory like the remnants of a dream. Since a year ago, when I began writing my book "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami" (Collection of Colloquial Poetry), I gathered scattered pieces about the Al Jarba family, like other families, from here and there to be my ammunition in interpreting this poetry only, and I did not know that these fragments would become a methodical research about the Al Jarba family. I published it as scattered benefits in the second part of "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami", then my Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser provided me with new benefits from the book "Matali' Al-Su'ud" by Ibn Sanad, and one benefit from the magazine "Lughat Al-Arab" published by Anastas Al-Karmali. Then he handed me what I was missing from the book "Asha'ir Al-Iraq" (Tribes of Iraq), which is the first part that expanded on the Al Jarba family, along with his corrections to the drafts of this research, leading to other information gathered with me, so I preferred to dedicate an independent research to Al Jarba. There is no doubt that the glimpses about them in books of history and genealogy do not give a complete picture, so I sought help - after Allah - from oral narration and colloquial poetry in completing this picture. I missed among the sources the book "Asha'ir Al-Sham" (Tribes of the Levant) by Wasfi Zakariya. The Al Jarba family is one of the families whose glories our country is proud of when they migrated to Iraq and Syria, so they were a national building in these two countries, and formed a Najdi literature there, and spread the customs and traditions of the country from which they migrated, except that what is not praised for the Shamamrah there is the disturbance of security, and the reintroduction of the custom of looting, plundering, and pre-Islamic revenge. Abdul Jabbar Al-Rawi narrated that Farhan Pasha bin Safouk Al Jarba said to the people of the village of Al-Mushahada in Iraq, admiring the hugeness of their bodies: Why don't you raid? They said: We are not good at raiding and cannot do it. He said: Raid those who are weaker (atqa') than you!! From my struggle with this research, it appeared to me that what was obscure in our history can be satisfied by observing elements that I hope our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser will take care of, and those for whom he paved the way who will come after him. These elements are summarized in the following: 1 - Taking care of the history, genealogy, and literature of other countries, where families and Bedouins migrated. And the succession of other events links Najd to others, so perhaps we find in the histories of Hijaz about Najd what we do not find in the books of the history of Najd. The figure is his figure and the features are his features ... But the deed is not the deed of the one with ample qualities *** A small caravan came to us from "Al-Arid" hurrying ... Following Ibn Arrouj, the leader of Bani Lam. And the most we find among the people of Najd is their saying: Ibn Arrouj is the last of the kings of Bani Lam. The story remains with us like a myth, until coincidences throw us to the books of the people of Iraq, so we find in the book "Ansab Al-Asha'ir Al-Arabiyyah fi Al-Najaf Al-Ashraf" (Genealogies of Arab Tribes in Holy Najaf) by Naji Wida'a Al-Sharis historical documentations confirming the Najdi literary narration. Al-Sharis mentioned a family in Najaf known as Al Shukr, from Al Hadid Al-Ahsa'i, who is Shukr bin Muhammad bin Shukr bin Hamoud Ibn Ali Al-Ahsa'i, one of the descendants of Yusuf bin Hadid bin Arrouj from Al Ghazzi from Al Fudul from Bani Lam. Al-Sharis's book is not of the type of conjectures found among our historians and genealogists, for he relied on endowment and inheritance papers such as an endowment deed for Al Thabit, dated 980 AH, an endowment deed for Hajj Nasir Ibn Ali Al-Ahsa'i, dated 1174 AH, and an endowment deed for Shukr bin Hamoud Al Hadid, dated 1225 AH. He quoted from the book "Ansab Al-Arab" (Genealogies of Arabs) by Samir Abdul Razzaq Al-Qutb that Hadid bin Arrouj was the last remaining in Najd from the clan of Al Ghazzi from Al Fudul, and mentioned about him that Hadid's leadership was after Ajl Ibn Hunaitim, and Muhammad bin Hadid took over after him. I benefited from this book in linking the chain of lineage between Al Faris, Al Rashid, and Al Ali. It will be used to link the chain for some settled families from the Bedouins. Joining such benefits crystallizes and scrutinizes some information of genealogists and historians in Najd.

text: I heard from my Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Uthman that one of the Mamluk sultans - and perhaps he referred to one of Al-Maqrizi's books - requested to meet some notables of Najd and referred me to the travelogue of Ibn Al-Mujawir regarding a text of colloquial poetry, and I found it as he said. I found in the history of Al-Isami by Muhammad bin Jadu' in praise of Barakat bin Ibrahim Al-Sharif a type of old colloquial poetry recorded by Ibn Yahya and published by Ibn Hatim. I found in the genealogies of the people of Oman what I connected with the history of some ruling families in Bahrain, in the first volume of my book on colloquial poetry. I knew with certainty from a poem by Al-Kulaif "Al-Julaif" that Muqrin Ibn Ghusayb recovered the kingdom of Al-Ahsa from Al Mughamis and that the Turks took over Al-Ahsa while the rulers were from Al Ajwad as Ibn Bishr and others said, but Ibn Bishr erred in the date only. In any case, the bibliographic project for these fragments helps students of knowledge to clarify their obscure history, especially after the opening of the public to manuscript treasuries, and the ease of photography. A decade ago, we used to see the historian's referral to a manuscript as a major merit. The Al Jarba family are from the princes of the Mountain (Jabal Shammar) and from a deeply rooted tribe in this homeland. Genealogists mentioned that the Tayy tribe left Yemen following the departure of Al-Azd from it, and settled in Samira and Fayd in the neighborhood of Bani Asad, then overcame Bani Asad over Aja and Salma, so they became known later as the two mountains of Tayy. Ibn Sa'id mentioned that they were the holders of leadership among the Arabs in his era in Iraq and the Levant. Their leadership was in Bani Rabi'ah bin Hazim from the descendants of Silsilah bin Ghanm from the descendants of Fitrah bin Tayy, for they inherited the land of Ghassan and the Levant, and among their most famous families are Al Isa bin Muhanna bin Fadl bin Rabi'ah, whom Ibn Fadlallah Al-Umari praised greatly. Our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser had written a book about Al Fadl in his youth and told me orally that the descendants of Al Fadl remain until now in Jordan. Shammar is a clan from Tayy, but in later ages it became a gathering of Tayy clans with other mixtures that entered into it by alliance. Ibn Dakhil attributed Al Ali and Al Rashid to Al Fadl, and he has no support except that they replaced them in place and emirate. As for genealogy books, they indicated that they are from Madhhij. If it is true that Abda is from Shammar - as quoted from the book attributed to Ibn Qudamah - then there is no doubt that their leaders Al Daigham are from Janb from Madhhij and they entered into Abda. Al Daigham until the end of the seventh Hijri century were still in the south in the land of Madhhij. It appears - seeking guidance from names - that Al Ali and Al Rashid are from the descendants of Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir bin Ali whom Ibn Rasul mentioned. Perhaps between their nearest grandfather Arar bin Shahwan and Shahwan bin Mansour is a grandfather named Faris bin Ta'an, seeking guidance from a text about Al Faris as will be explained. I attributed them to Faris bin Ta'an because Al Khalil are the sons of Khalil bin Jasser bin Ali bin Atiyyah from Al Ja'far, and Al-Sharis mentioned that Al Faris and Al Khalil are one clan and Ibn Faris Muhammad was alive in 1109. Then he mentioned that Al Sadiq are from the descendants of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali from Al Faris. If Al Sadiq are cousins of Al Ali and they were from Al Faris bin Ta'an, then Al Ali are from the descendants of Faris. All of them are from Al Ja'far, and Ibn Bassam mentioned that Al Ja'far are from the Daighams. For all this, I preferred that Al Ali and Al Rashid have a grandfather named Faris Ibn Ta'an, either from the descendants of Arar bin Shahwan or between Arar bin Shahwan and Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham. In any case, inserting Faris bin Ta'an into the lineage of Al Rashid is a deduction that remains a mere probability. In Ibn Rasul's text, Munif bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir had a son named Rashid and he had a grandson named Umair bin Ahmad bin Rashid. In the unknown author's book from which Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser quoted the news of the black Shahwani horses in his manuscript on horses, Shahwan is the father of Arar or Rashid is the uncle of Umair. It is possible that Arar is a grandson of Munif bin Daigham. It is possible that he is from the descendants of Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham. In any case, the inheritance of the name Shahwan, Umair, and Rashid confirms that Arar bin Shahwan and Umair bin Rashid are from the descendants of Munif bin Daigham. Al Jarba are the leaders of Shammar and the heads of the Mountain, and the furthest mention I found of them is about the death of two of them in the year 1100 AH and the year 1103 AH. They left Najd in the year 1205 AH after their defeat before Ibn Saud, so they built their leadership in Iraq and Syria. text: Ubaidah from Qahtan said: If you ask about us, O Suwaiti, Qahtanis ... 'Awasim, and those beside us are superior. We and Abda and the Daighams are two grandfathers ... Slappers on the day of meeting to every arrogant one. The princes of the Mountain after Al Jarban are Al Ali, and there is much confusion about them in history. Scholars have buried the first era of the emirate of Isa bin Ali, which resulted in confusion between the events of Abdullah Ibn Rashid in the era of Isa the first and the era of Salih bin Abdul Muhsin and the era of Isa bin Ali for the second time. I have verified the order of their rule as follows: 1 - Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez bin Muhammad bin Isa bin Ali bin Ali bin Atiyyah. He was the Emir of the Mountain in the era of Imam Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad and entered into his obedience in the year 1201 AH. 2 - Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin took over in the year 1201 AH. 3 - Isa bin Ali took over in the year 1234 AH. 4 - Salih bin Abdul Muhsin took over in the year 1249 AH. 5 - Ibn Rashid took over in the year 1250 AH. 6 - Isa bin Ali took over a second time in the year 1253 AH. Then Abdullah bin Rashid expelled him in the same year, and thus the emirate of Al Ali ended. This arrangement came after verification, scrutiny, and discussions. After Al Ali came Al Rashid, and Dr. Abdullah Al-Salih Al-Uthaymin wrote an extremely verified and scrutinized appendix titled "The Emergence of the Emirate of Al Rashid" published by the Deanship of Library Affairs at Riyadh University in 1981 AD and printed by the Middle East Press in Riyadh. He touched in this appendix upon the princes of the Mountain before Abdullah bin Rashid. Dr. Al-Uthaymin's appendix is a pioneering study in dealing with our local history, in terms of deduction and benefiting from colloquial poetry and what foreigners wrote. Dr. Al-Uthaymin's attention was to history intentionally, and to colloquial poetry consequentially. I dealt with the history of Abdullah bin Al-Rashid in the second volume of my book "The History of Najd in the Colloquial Ages" with the opposite of this method, which is that I intended colloquial poetry and leaned on history to complete the study from poetry. When I compared what I wrote with what Dr. Al-Uthaymin wrote, I saw in his sources a capacity for me, and in his outputs and deductions landmarks by which I was guided. I saw in Dr. Al-Uthaymin's appendix something that must be rectified without prejudice to the originality of his research and its accuracy. And I saw in my research something that must be added to the Doctor's research to be complete according to the tool possessed by the researcher in this era. It is good to bring a brief about Al Ali who succeeded Al Jarba in leadership. I previously mentioned in the talk about Al Jarba that they are from Abda from Shammar, and that Abda is from Al Daigham. Al Rashid are the closest cousins of Al Ali. Dr. Ibn Uthaymin chained the lineage of Prince Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin as follows: Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez bin Muhammad bin Isa bin Ali Ibn Ali Al-Kabir, in whom the lineage of this family meets with the lineage of Al Rashid. The Doctor did not mention his source. Sulaiman Al-Dakhil said about Abdullah Al-Rashid: Abdullah Ali bin Rashid bin Khalil bin Atiyyah. And Khalil is the brother of Ali the grandfather of Al Ali. Dr. Al-Uthaymin quoted from a paper with Nayef Al Ali in Hail: Abdullah bin Ali bin Hamad bin Rashid bin Khudair bin Khalil Ibn Yasir bin Ali bin Atiyyah. Al-Uthaymin said: And what Dhari mentioned agrees with Nayef's paper, except that Hamad is a father to Rashid, not a son to him. Ibn Bishr said about Jabr, the uncle of Abdullah bin Rashid: Jabr bin Rashid bin Ali. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: It appears to me that Ali Al-Kabir is the grandfather of Al Sadiq in Najaf, for their grandfather Hajj Ahmad was alive in the year 1185 AH and he is the son of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali from Shammar Abda. It appears that Ali Al-Kabir bin Atiyyah's lineage goes back to Faris Ibn Ta'an, the grandfather of Al Faras in Najaf. Al-Sharis said about Al Faris: One of the branches of Al Ja'far from the tribe of Shammar Abda Al-Ta'iyyah Al-Qahtaniyyah, and Al-Azzawi mentioned them in his book "Asha'ir Al-Iraq" (Tribes of Iraq) the Bedouin ones, and they are Al Khalil, one clan. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The context of lineage from these texts for these families aligns on this tree. Faris bin Ta'an, from his descendants Ali Al-Kabir bin Atiyyah, Muhammad grandfather of Al Sadiq, Ali Isa grandfather of Al Ali, Jasser grandfather of Al Rashid.

text: On this basis, it is correct to say that Al Rashid are from Al Ali as Al-Dakhil said, and that they are cousins of Al Ali as the majority say. This is the most I saw in the chain of lineage. As for the general genealogy books, they mention Al Rashid from Al Khalil from Al Ja'afara from Al Dughairat from Al Yahya from Abda from Shammar. Yusuf Al-Bassam said: And Al Ja'far are from the Daighams from Shammar Abda. I saw Abdullah Al-Khalid Al-Hatim mentioning that Arar bin Shahwan Al Daigham, the grandfather of Al Rashid, princes of Jabal Hail, lived in the year 850 AH. My Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser leaned towards this in his book "Jamharat Ansab Al-Usar Al-Mutahaddira" (Collection of Genealogies of Settled Families), so he attributed them to Al Daigham, and quoted from the book "Turfat Al-Ashab fi Ma'rifat Al-Ansab" by Umar bin Yusuf Ibn Rasul "... - 694 AH" that Al Daigham were until the end of the seventh Hijri century still in the south in the land of Madhhij "land of Qahtan now in the region of Asir Emirate" and he named them Al Munif and attributed them to Janb. Their grandfather is Munif bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir bin Ali Ibn Abd al-Rabb bin Rabi' bin Sulaiman bin Abd al-Rahman bin Ruh Ibn Mudrik bin Abd al-Hamid bin Mudrik. It is said that they are from Nizar - from Anz bin Wa'il bin Qasit, entered into the lineage of Janb, because their mother Ubaidah bint Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah Al-Taghlibi was married by Ruh bin Mudrik. They have poems about their journey, parts of which were mentioned by Sheikhs Al-Aboudi and Al-Junaidil in their dictionaries and Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser in his manuscript book "Mu'jam Al-Khail" (Dictionary of Horses). I hinted at something of that in the first volume of my book on colloquial poetry. The attribution of Al Rashid to Al Daigham is present in colloquial poetry. Abdullah bin Rashid said rebuking his group: From the door of Khaddam to the door of Shaddad ... And whoever prides himself on the Daighamiya, it paints him. Mukhlid bin Hadeires praising Abdullah bin Rashid said: The Daighami from Hail crossed the highlands ... Sent the scouts and began gathering its sides. Ali Al-Qabali Al-Tamimi said: The Daighami fills his cloak with all virility ... And we pick up what fell on the soil. Ibn Hadeires said: Abu Talal the Daighami, the elite of the children ... The leader of Ghalba in the meeting, confronting the wandering. Mani' Al-Qu'ud praising Abdul Aziz bin Mutaib Al-Rashid said: Mock the Daighams, O namesake of the dog Sadhan ... Mock the Daighams, and the Daighams are an illness to the enemy. Sulaiman bin Jumhur said: Nothing happened like the Daighami when he disappeared ... He turned away from the eye of the bad one by retreating. Ubaid bin Ali bin Rashid said: Daighams who cheapen the camels and the necks ... And for the companion with their wealth they are not stingy. And he said praising his brother Abdullah: They follow a gallant one whose maternal uncles are his paternal uncles ... From Daigham, no vein of strangers mixed in him. And he said praising his nephew Talal: Daighams who come to the basin of crowding ... They come to it when the substitutes cover the people.

text: Except that Al-Azzawi quoted from the book "Majma' Al-Ansab" which he attributed to Ibn Qudamah that Abda is from Shammar. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Based on this, the Qahtanis - from other than Tayy - are Al Daigham who entered into Abda by alliance. Information about Al Ali is incomplete, and what information is found about them has much confusion. Dr. Ibn Uthaymin: Sees that the emirate of Hail during the twelfth Hijri century belonged to Al Ali belonging to Al Ja'far. He counted among the princes of this century Muhammad the First, who is Muhammad bin Isa Ibn Ali, brother of Khansa, or Al-Samn Al-Arabi. As for Sheikh Ali bin Salim, he mentions that the first of the princes of Al Ali is Abdul Muhsin bin Ali. Then he said in another place: I do not have a statement of the time of their mandate and how they became extinct, but they are from the year 1232. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Abdul Muhsin was the Emir of Hail in the era of Imam Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad and entered into the obedience of the Imam in the year 1201 AH, thus their beginning is before the year 1201 and the saying of Ibn Salim falls: that they are from the year 1232 AH. As for Dr. Al-Uthaymin, he dropped the era of this Abdul Muhsin, and said: The Emir at the end of the twelfth century is Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Muhammad only took over after his father Abdul Muhsin at the beginning of the thirteenth century. Al-Uthaymin quoted from the book "Kaifa Kana Zuhur Sheikh Al-Islam Muhammad bin Abd al-Wahhab" by an unknown author: That Hujailan in the year 1201 killed a sorcerer and installed Muhammad bin Ali as a sheikh in the region. He commented on that saying: Perhaps Hujailan confirmed Muhammad bin Ali in the leadership of the Mountain. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: I previously mentioned Ibn Salim's text that Abdul Muhsin was the Emir of Hail before his son, and Yusuf Al-Bassam mentioned: That Hujailan appointed Muhammad after the death of his father Abdul Muhsin. These two texts in addition to the text of the author of the book "Kaifa Kana Zuhur Sheikh Al-Islam" support the precedence of Abdul Muhsin's emirate and Dr. Al-Uthaymin has no additional knowledge to negate that. It appears that Shammar submitted to the call of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd al-Wahhab during his life, and the life of Imam Muhammad bin Saud shortly before the year 1178 AH because the author of the book "Lam' Al-Shihab" mentioned in the events of this year that Muhammad bin Saud prepared an army of six thousand, led by his son Abdul Aziz by order of Muhammad bin Abd al-Wahhab, and sent it to a group of Shammar, who had entered into obedience before that and when they heard of the coming of Al-Najrani and Ar'ar they apostatized from the rule of Ibn Saud, and began raiding his outskirts, so Abdul Aziz marched with the army to Jabal Shammar and raided them at night, destroying a large group of them and capturing two hundred men or more. As for Al Ali themselves and the settled people of the Mountain, they submitted to the rule of Al Saud since the year 1201 AH. For that, there are two premises: The first: That the Shammar tribe in the year 1196 supported Sa'dun Ibn Uray'ir in his siege of Hujailan, the Emir of Buraydah on behalf of Al Saud. The second: That Shammar in Muharram of the year 1201 AH supported Thuwaini bin Abdullah, in his attack on Najd, and his siege of Qassim and Hujailan in Buraydah. Perhaps as a result of the first premise: Hujailan's raid was in the year 1200 AH where he took a caravan of Shammar and killed many of them. And as a result of the second premise with certainty: Hujailan raided by order of Imam Abdul Aziz the land of Shammar and brought them into obedience, so they pledged allegiance to Ibn Saud. This Muhammad is one of the most famous princes of Al Ali. Among the historical events in his era is that he raided the Shararat tribe in Al-Jawf in the year 1207 AH with four hundred camels and fifty horses but the result of his raid was a failure. In the year 1208 he attacked Al-Jawf and brought it into the obedience of Al Saud, so Imam Saud bin Abdul Aziz annexed the province of Al-Jawf to him. In the year 1211 AH, the people of the Mountain participated with the Saudi forces in repelling Thuwaini's campaign. It was mentioned that Muhammad raided the region of Iraq and clashed with Al Bu'ayj and killed fifty men of them. In the year 1221 AH, Muhammad was among the leaders stationed around Medina, by order of Imam Saud, to force the Emir of the Levant pilgrims to return to his country. In the year 1225 AH, the people of the Mountain were with Imam Saud in his raid on the Levantine lands. In the year 1228 AH, Imam Saud tasked Muhammad with monitoring a division of the Ottoman Egyptian army to force it to go to Iraq. In the year 1229 AH, Muhammad participated with the Saudi forces in their failed disciplinary attack on Ayyad Al-Dhuwaibi Al-Harbi near Al-Hinakiyah. Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser mentioned that the rulers of Hail, Al Ali and Al Rashid, lived in Al-Suwaifilah, before moving to Hail, and I cited his text in the poetry of Abdullah bin Rashid while discussing his poem on the rhyme of Ta and Ra connected with Ha in the second volume of my book "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami". In another text, Al-Jasser mentioned that the capital of the emirate Al-Safilah "Al-Suwaifilah" was built in the eighth century and soon fell into ruin, so Hail was built in its wake. He said in a third place about Al-Samra: "It is said that it is ancient Hail and that it was the seat of Al Ali". Ibn Uthaymin said: "The dwellings of Al Ali were at the bottom of the base of the mountain or what is known as Al-Suwaifilah". Then their leaders built a palace for themselves in a place called Al-Washiqi, three kilometers from their first dwellings. After that, Prince Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin founded the famous Barzan Palace, which later became the palace of Al Rashid's rule. It is said that the palace was named Barzan because of its prominence (baruz) from their first dwelling. In the previous text, Al-Uthaymin mentioned that Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin was the one who founded Barzan Palace, and said in another place: He laid the foundation of the famous Barzan. Al-Zirikli said about Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Rashid: He completed Barzan Palace in Hail, and Isa bin Ali had started building it. I cannot reconcile these two texts except that Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin founded it and Isa completed it, and Muhammad Al-Abdullah renovated and expanded it. Our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser did not touch upon the relationship of Barzan to Al Ali, but said: A palace that was in the city of Hail during the Rashidi Emirate era, and drew its location in the book "Al-Qawl Al-Sadid" by Ibn Dakhil, and some of its buildings were photographed in the book "Introduction to Antiquities in the Kingdom" issued by the Ministry of Education in 1396 AH. Huber mentioned in his journey: That Abdullah bin Ali bin Rashid bought Barzan Palace from Al Ali. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The fame of Barzan Palace is only in the era of Al Rashid. Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser mentioned that the rulers of Hail, Al Ali and Al Rashid, lived in Al-Suwaifilah, before moving to Hail, and I cited his text in the poetry of Abdullah bin Rashid while discussing his poem on the rhyme of Ta and Ra connected with Ha in the second volume of my book "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami". In another text, Al-Jasser mentioned that the capital of the emirate Al-Safilah "Al-Suwaifilah" was built in the eighth century and soon fell into ruin, so Hail was built in its wake. He said in a third place about Al-Samra: "It is said that it is ancient Hail and that it was the seat of Al Ali". Ibn Uthaymin said: "The dwellings of Al Ali were at the bottom of the base of the mountain or what is known as Al-Suwaifilah". Then their leaders built a palace for themselves in a place called Al-Washiqi, three kilometers from their first dwellings. After that, Prince Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin founded the famous Barzan Palace, which later became the palace of Al Rashid's rule. It is said that the palace was named Barzan because of its prominence (baruz) from their first dwelling. In the previous text, Al-Uthaymin mentioned that Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin was the one who founded Barzan Palace, and said in another place: He laid the foundation of the famous Barzan. Al-Zirikli said about Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Rashid: He completed Barzan Palace in Hail, and Isa bin Ali had started building it. I cannot reconcile these two texts except that Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin founded it and Isa completed it, and Muhammad Al-Abdullah renovated and expanded it. Our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser did not touch upon the relationship of Barzan to Al Ali, but said: A palace that was in the city of Hail during the Rashidi Emirate era, and drew its location in the book "Al-Qawl Al-Sadid" by Ibn Dakhil, and some of its buildings were photographed in the book "Introduction to Antiquities in the Kingdom" issued by the Ministry of Education in 1396 AH. Huber mentioned in his journey: That Abdullah bin Ali bin Rashid bought Barzan Palace from Al Ali. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The fame of Barzan Palace is only in the era of Al Rashid. Rakan bin Hithlain said: O my she-camel, cross the peaks of Tumiya ... Head towards Barzan, the beautiful building. And Hamoud bin Ubaid bin Rashid said: If Ibn Hindi intended us at Barzan ... Then we at Arwa shortened the march.

text: Muhammad remained Emir of the Mountain for nearly thirty-three years, as he took over around the year 1201 and was killed in the year 1234. The reason for that is that Ibrahim Pasha, when he eliminated the Saudi state, launched a campaign against the emirs of the regions enthusiastic for the Call and its supporters Al Saud, and for this he killed Muhammad and his brother Ali in the year 1234 AH. Ibn Uthaymin said: Al-Habashi, the leader of Ibrahim Pasha's men, assassinated him by a trick in Maqsurat Al-Dahis, then cut off his head and sent it to Turkey. The poet refers to this saying: What a pity, the head of the Sheikh, the owls play with it ... Facing each other, cutting it up. As for the rest of his body, it was buried in Al-Zubara cemetery in Hail, and I saw his grave with written on one of its stones: "Muhammad bin Ali, may Allah have mercy on him and dwell him" and dwell him "Dar Al-Salam" (House of Peace). The phrase 'Emir of the Muslims' indicates that he was famous for religiosity, as it indicates that he was great, which supports what was mentioned of his enthusiasm for the call of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd al-Wahhab, and the role he had in the state based on his call. Prince Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin left four daughters, one of whom is Salma who married Abdullah bin Ali bin Rashid. Sheikh Ali bin Salim said: "As for Muhammad bin Ali, the Turks killed him during their appearance in Najd at Barzan Palace in Hail when they besieged him and brought him down by force and killed him". And now his grave is in Al-Zubara cemetery in Hail, a body without a head. Thus I heard from my father, may Allah have mercy on him, saying that, and I do not know which year that was, so Allah knows best. Dr. Al-Uthaymin mentioned: That Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin advised the people of Qafar during the invasion of Ibrahim Pasha to build a palace part of which is at a level lower than the surface of the nearby ground so that cannons would not affect it. After the killing of Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin, we do not know who took over directly after him, except that it is certain that Isa bin Ali bin Fayez took over before Salih bin Abdul Muhsin. The proof for that is as follows: A - The indication of Abdullah bin Rashid's Daliyah poem which I preferred was in the first period of Isa's rule, as I explained in the second volume of my book "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami". B - Ibn Bishr mentioned that in the year 1243 or 1242 AH, Isa Ibn Ali bin Fayez, the head of Jabal Shammar, came to Imam Turki and pledged allegiance, and placed Hamad Al-Shuwai'ir in the treasury of the Mountain. Ibn Bishr described him in the year 1253 as the old head of the Mountain. C - That Imam Turki bin Abdullah did not appoint Salih bin Abdul Muhsin except in the year 1249 AH. Dr. Al-Uthaymin excludes the mandate of Isa bin Ali directly after Muhammad Ibn Abdul Muhsin and argues with the following: A - Ibn Bishr's saying about Isa "Head of the Mountain" does not indicate a previous presidency, because Ibn Bishr's habit is to describe with presidency whoever will hold it, then he mentioned examples for that. B - That Ibn Rashid took the emirate from Salih bin Abdul Muhsin by agreement of sources. C - That Ibn Bishr mentioned Salih among Turki's emirs when speaking about his assassination. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The answer to this is as follows: 1 - That Ibn Bishr sometimes creates ambiguity by describing with presidency whoever will hold it but hasn't held it yet. But this time he removed the ambiguity by saying "the old head of the Mountain", so it is correct that Ibn Bishr described Isa with presidency because he was a head in the past. 2 - There is no doubt that Ibn Rashid took over the emirate after Salih bin Abdul Muhsin by agreement of sources. But the sources did not agree that Salih took over directly after Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin, rather Ibn Bishr stated that Turki appointed him in 1249 AH. 3 - That Ibn Bishr, when he mentioned his arrival in the year 1243 AH, described him as the head and the pledge of allegiance. This is an actual definition of the head in reality. 4 - Ibn Bishr only mentioned Salih as an emir when mentioning the emirs of Turki, because he was the emir at the time of Turki's death. Ibn Bishr only mentions the Imam's emirs at the time of his death, and does not commit to mentioning everyone who commanded in his life. Thus Dr. Al-Uthaymin's probability that Isa was merely an influential person in the era of Emir Salih falls. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: This Isa is likely to be: Isa bin Ali bin Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez bin Ali. So his father would be Ali, the brother of Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin, whom Ibrahim Pasha killed with his brother. And Ibn Bishr's saying: Isa bin Ali bin Fayez, would be by way of abbreviation, which is a familiar matter. It is also possible that Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez had a brother named Ali, so he would be Isa bin Ali bin Fayez bin Ali. As for Dr. Al-Uthaymin, he cited regarding him the following:

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: A - Musil's saying: Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin was succeeded by his son Isa. So he is Isa bin Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez bin Ali and our friend is Isa bin Ali bin Fayez. They are two without doubt, and it is far-fetched that the second name is an abbreviation of the first, because it is an unfamiliar confusion in the abbreviation of genealogists and historians. Al-Uthaymin quoted from some Al Ali residing in Hail that Muhammad did not father a male. This is a refutation of Musil's saying without doubt. B - The saying of Dhari Al-Rashid and "Huber" that our friend is Isa Ibn Ubaidullah. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: We did not find a notable with historical events by this name, and it is impossible that the Emir of the Mountain is Isa bin Ubaidullah and Ibn Bishr calls him: Isa bin Ali bin Fayez! Al-Uthaymin mentioned that it was stated in a paper with Sayyid Nayef Al Ali in Hail that Abdullah is a cousin of Salih bin Abdul Muhsin. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: We do not deny the existence of someone named Ubaidullah or Isa in Al Ali, but we deny that Isa bin Ubaidullah is Isa bin Ali bin Fayez the Emir. Al-Uthaymin said: As for the Al Ali family present today, they are from the descendants of Isa bin Salih bin Abdul Muhsin. This Isa was a child when the events befell his father, so his mother hid him until matters settled later. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: So this Isa's era of eligibility for mandate is different from the era of Isa bin Ali bin Fayez. After Isa, Salih bin Abdul Muhsin took over, appointed by Imam Turki in the year 1249 AH as passed previously, then Imam Faisal removed him in the year 1250 AH and appointed Abdullah bin Rashid. I explained in the second volume of my book "Diwan Al-Shi'r Al-'Ami" the story of Salih's killing and that Ubaid bin Ali bin Rashid was the one who killed him. In the year 1253, the aforementioned Isa bin Ali seized Hail and expelled Abdullah bin Rashid, then Abdullah expelled him in the same year and thus the emirate of Ali ended. Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin, who is the most prominent leader from Al Ali, Dr. Al-Uthaymin cited his lineage as follows: Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin Ibn Fayez bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Ali Al-Kabir. And it appeared in Ibn Bishr: Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin bin Fayez Ibn Ali and sometimes Muhammad bin Abdul Muhsin bin Ali, so we interpret Ibn Bishr's context as abbreviation. As for Dr. Al-Uthaymin, perhaps he relied on documents with Al Ali in Hail. The fact that Muhammad is the Emir after his father is not a place of confusion, but Ibn Salim said: "The first kings of Al Ali are Abdul Muhsin bin Ali and after him his son Salih bin Abdul Muhsin and after him Muhammad bin Ali". Al-Marik commented on that saying: And after Muhammad "i.e. Ibn Ali" his brother Salih bin Ali. So his word 'Akhu' (brother) without Ha caused confusion, except that Sheikh Hamad quoted this text a second time and removed the confusion when he said: For the one who took over the emirate after Muhammad bin Ali is his brother Salih bin Ali according to what Professor Fahd Al-Marik informed me. In any case, the subject needs detailing which is not the place for here. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Muhammad bin Ali is before his brother Salih contrary to what Ibn Salim claimed. And after Muhammad bin Ali: Isa bin Ali before Salih bin Ali and this is what Al-Marik missed. Ibn Salim claimed that Abdul Muhsin has a mention in the history of Ibn Bishr. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Ibn Bishr did not mention him, he only mentioned his son Muhammad and Salih. Since my benefit from the first part of "Asha'ir Al-Iraq" and from the magazine "Lughat Al-Arab" was after I edited the material of this research, I preferred keeping my research as it is provided that I make the texts of "Asha'ir Al-Iraq" and "Lughat Al-Arab" two verified appendices at the end of the book. In conclusion of this preface, I offer my sincere thanks to the teacher of the generation Hamad Al-Jasser who offered me his support and guidance, and I hope that the deficiencies of this book will be completed by what is in his manuscript on horses of news and poems of Al Daigham, and Allah is the Helper. Written for you by Abu Abd al-Rahman bin Aqeel Al-Zahiri Riyadh 9/4/1402 AH Then finished revising it on 30/4/1402 AH Al Jarba Family 2 - Their lineage, and the story of their departure from the South to the land of Al-Mahbalin, then their journey to Iraq and Syria. Lineage of Al Jarba

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: It is agreed upon among genealogists that Al Jarba are from Abda from Shammar. A section of them entered into Sinjara from Shammar, and they are still now in Syria under the leadership of Mizar Al Jarba, Sheikh of Al-Fadaghah, and Daham Al Jarba, Sheikh of Al-Kharsa. Shammar is a clan from Tha'labah bin Amr from Tayy as Ibn Al-Kalbi said. It is today one of the major Arab tribes. When Ibn La'bun spoke about Shammar the father of the tribe, he said: This attribution Shammar has prevailed over the people of Jabal Tayy from the Bedouins and some of the settled people, and it appears that not all of them are from his descendants, and it is not unlikely that others who meet with him in his lineage column from the rest of Tayy are attributed to him, as well as those who mixed with them or settled with them from neighbor or ally may be attributed to them, with the passage of time. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: So Abda is one of the largest Shammar tribes of Tayy by alliance, and it is from the tribe of Janb of Madhhij by lineage. They are cousins of Ubaidah from Qahtan. A poet from Ubaidah from Qahtan said: If you ask about us, O Suwaiti, Qahtanis ... 'Awasim and those beside us are superior. We and Abda and the Daighams are two grandfathers ... Slappers on the day of meeting to every arrogant one.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: As for the general Tayy, genealogists mentioned that the Tayy tribe left Yemen following the departure of Al-Azd from it, and settled in Samira and Fayd, in the neighborhood of Bani Asad, then overcame Bani Asad over Aja and Salma, so they became known later as the two mountains of Tayy. Ibn Sa'id mentioned the holders of leadership among the Arabs in his era in Iraq and the Levant. Their leadership was in Bani Rabi'ah bin Hazim, from the descendants of Fitrah bin Tayy, for they inherited the land of Ghassan and the Levant, and among their most famous families are Al Isa bin Muhanna bin Fadl bin Rabi'ah, whom Ibn Fadlallah Al-Umari praised greatly. Our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser had written a book about Al Fadl in his youth, and told me orally that the descendants of Al Fadl remain until now in Jordan. Shammar is a clan from Tayy, but in later ages it became a gathering of Tayy clans with other mixtures that entered into it by alliance. Ibn Dakhil attributed Al Ali and Al Rashid to Al Fadl, and he has no support except that they replaced them in place and emirate. As for genealogy books, they indicated that they are from Madhhij. If it is true that Abda is from Shammar - as quoted from Ibn Qudamah - then there is no doubt that their leaders Al Daigham are from Janb from Madhhij, and they entered into Abda. Al Daigham until the end of the seventh Hijri century were still in the south in the land of Madhhij. It appears - seeking guidance from names - that Al Ali and Al Rashid are from the descendants of Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir bin Ali, whom Ibn Rasul mentioned in his book "Turfat Al-Ashab". Perhaps between their nearest grandfather Arar bin Shahwan and Shahwan bin Mansour is a grandfather named Faris bin Ta'an, seeking guidance from a text about Al Faris as will be explained. I attributed them to Faris bin Ta'an because Al Khalil are the sons of Khalil bin Jasser bin Ali bin Atiyyah from Al Ja'far, and Al-Sharis mentioned that Al Faris and Al Khalil are one clan, and Ibn Faris Muhammad was alive in 1109 AH. Then he mentioned that Al Sadiq are from the descendants of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali from Al Faris, so if Al Sadiq are cousins of Al Ali and they were from Al Faris bin Ta'an, then Al Ali are from the descendants of Faris. All of them are from Al Ja'far, and Ibn Bassam mentioned that Al Ja'far are from the Daighams. For all this, I preferred that Al Ali and Al Rashid have a grandfather named Faris Ibn Ta'an, either from the descendants of Arar bin Shahwan, or between Arar bin Shahwan and Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham. In any case, inserting Faris bin Ta'an into the lineage of Al Rashid is a deduction that remains a mere probability. In Ibn Rasul's text, Munif bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir had a son named Rashid and he had a grandson named Umair bin Ahmad bin Rashid. In the unknown author's book from which Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser quoted the news of the black Shahwani horses in his manuscript on horses, Shahwan the father of Arar is the brother of Rashid the uncle of Umair. It is possible that Arar is a grandson of Munif bin Daigham. It is possible that he is from the descendants of Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham. In any case, the inheritance of the name Shahwan, Umair, and Rashid confirms that Arar bin Shahwan and Umair bin Rashid are from the descendants of Munif bin Daigham. Ibn Mughira said about Al Jarban and about the general lineage of Abda: And Al Saih is a clan from Shammar, and they are clans and thighs, among them Al Jarban the third clan from Shammar Abda: They are Banu Daigham Ibn Muawiyah bin Al-Harith bin Munabbih bin Yazid bin Harb bin Ulah Ibn Jald bin Madhhij brother of Tayy. Muawiyah bin Al-Harith was from Janb and the kingship was in the house of Janb, and he is the one whom Muhalhil the brother of Kulaib sought refuge with, and he married the daughter of Muhalhil named Ubaidah, and to her belong tribes from Janb, so she bore him the father of the tribe Daigham. From Banu Daigham are these Abda and they had the leadership over the tribes of Shammar from Tayy bin Ali "?". The leadership of Jabal Tayy was formerly for Jadilah a clan from Tayy then it became in Bani Nabhan then it became in Al Jarban. Then it became in Abda in Al Ja'far. Abu Abd al-Rahman said about Ibn Mughira's words: This is misspelling and confusion, and I will join to it a text by Ibn Rasul hoping it removes some of Ibn Mughira's ambiguity. Our Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser said: It came in the book "Turfat Al-Ashab fi Ma'rifat Al-Ansab" by Sultan Umar bin Yusuf Ibn Rasul who died in the year 694: The lineage of Al Munif who are Al Daigham and Al Rashid is from Janb, and they are known as Al-Ma'dah. He is Munif bin Daigham bin Munif bin Jabir bin Ali bin Abd al-Rabb bin Rabi' bin Sulaiman bin Abd al-Rahman bin Ruh bin Mudrik bin Abd al-Hamid bin Mudrik. It is said: They are from Bakil, but they allied with Ans from Madhhij so they were named Janb. And it is said: They are from Nizar from Anz bin Wa'il bin Qasit Ibn Hanb bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah Ibn Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan. They entered into

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: The lineage of Janb, because their mother Ubaidah bint Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah Al-Taghlibi, from Taghlib bin Wa'il the brother of Anz bin Wa'il, was married by Ruh bin Mudrik after Muawiyah bin Amr Ibn Muawiyah bin Al-Harith Al-Janbi. Their brothers from their mother are Al Ayidh, Al Rashid, Banu Qais, Al Safar, Al Salt, and their companions, called Al-Abtun, from the children of this Muawiyah Al-Janbi so they were attributed to them. So Al Daigham bin Munif and his children are eight: Munif, Shukr, Isa, Ali, Mansour, Shaiban, Amir, and Harith. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: From Ibn Rasul's text and Ibn Mughira's text the following becomes clear: Janb, because their mother Ubaidah bint Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah Al-Taghlibi, from Taghlib bin Wa'il the brother of Anz bin Wa'il, was married by Ruh bin Mudrik after Muawiyah bin Amr Ibn Muawiyah bin Al-Harith Al-Janbi. Their brothers from their mother are Al Ayidh, Al Rashid, Banu Qais, Al Safar, Al Salt, and their companions, called Al-Abtun, from the children of this Muawiyah Al-Janbi so they were attributed to them. So Al Daigham bin Munif and his children are eight: Munif, Shukr, Isa, Ali, Mansour, Shaiban, Amir, and Harith. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: From Ibn Rasul's text and Ibn Mughira's text the following becomes clear: 1 - That Abda is not attributed to Shammar by returning to the grandfather Shammar, but they meet with Shammar in Udad bin Zaid, the father of Tayy from whose descendants are Banu Shammar, and Malik from whose descendants are Abda. There is a disagreement among genealogists whether "Madhhij" is a title for Malik bin Udad or is a name for the mother of Tayy and Malik. 2 - That the tribes of Abda are from the descendants of Daigham bin Muawiyah bin Al-Harith and Daigham's mother is Ubaidah bint Muhalhil. Except that Abu Hazm made Ubaidah's husband from the descendants of Muawiyah bin Al-Harith saying: And from Bani Yazid bin Harb bin Ulah Ibn Jald bin Malik "Madhhij": Muawiyah bin Amr bin Muawiyah bin Al-Harith bin Munabbih bin Yazid bin Harb bin Ali who married the daughter of Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah Al-Taghlibi in Najran and gave her leather as dowry, so her father said about that: Her loss of Al-Araqin married her off, in ... Janb and the gift was of leather. If he had come to propose to her at Abanain ... No nose of a suitor would have been stained with blood.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: 3 - The reason for Abda entering into Janb is that they are from the descendants of Daigham bin Muawiyah bin Al-Harith and his grandfather Munabbih bin Yazid bin Harb is one of the brothers who were included in the name Janb. Ibn Hazm said: Yazid bin Harb bin Ulah bin Jald Ibn Malik "Madhhij" begot: Munabbih, Al-Harith, Al-Ghali, Sanhan, Haffan, and Shimran. These six allied against the son of their brother Suda Ibn Yazid, so they were named Janb, along with their cousins Banu Sa'd Al-Ashirah bin Malik bin Ulah bin Jald bin Malik, who is Madhhij. Al-Azzawi quoted from the book "Majma' Al-Ansab" that Abda is from Shammar. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Ibn Mughira's text agrees with the text of Sultan Umar bin Yusuf bin Rasul. It came in this text that Al Daigham were until the end of the seventh century - which is the era of Ibn Rasul - still in the south in the land of Madhhij, and he attributed them to Janb, and mentioned another view in their attribution to Anz bin Wa'il from Nizar, and that they entered into Janb because their mother Ubaidah bint Muhalhil was married by Ruh bin Mudrik. There is no doubt that what is known now among Abda is their attribution to Daigham, and there are evidences for that from colloquial poetry. My Sheikh, the scholar of the Peninsula Hamad Al-Jasser - may Allah preserve him - informed me that Charles Huber quoted from Ubaid bin Ali bin Rashid the news of his ancestors moving from the south to the two mountains in a way resembling the story of Tayy's move from Wadi Tarib in the south to the two mountains. This means Al Rashid's acknowledgment that they are Al Daigham. Lady Anne Blunt quoted from Muhammad bin Rashid that the Shammar who are in the Peninsula and the Shammar his followers consider themselves relatives of womb kinship and said: The blood of our horses is one. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: There is a curious opinion attributing Al Jarba to Al Fadl which is what came in the book "Kanz Al-Ansab" quoting from the magazine "Lughat Al-Arab" of Baghdad titled Banu Taghlib Al-Adnaniyyah. Then I asked after that one of the great Sheikhs, Sheikh Mijwel Al Jarba, head of the Shammar tribes, about Taghlib and whether they have a remnant existing in the northern lands, but he did not mention anything of that to me, rather he excused himself from identifying the clan apologizing for that by the change of names on him, and he did not deny completely the existence of a remnant of them. When I mentioned Al Fudul to him, he was pleased, and relieved by this name very much, as if he was asleep and woke up, then said: It is close to the truth, then thought for a moment and said: Rather it is the truth itself, and counted for me from them Mutlaq and Bunayyah Al Jarba, heads of Shammar i.e. the first grandfather founder of the emirate of Shammar in Jabal Tayy, and that was when its first famous men appeared with this name. He mentioned after that things indicating the truth of his saying, then said: Al Fudul merged into the tribes, and scattered in the lands, and cited numerous proofs to support this statement of his. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: This is a statement I copied from the papers of my Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser then I reviewed the magazine "Lughat Al-Arab" and found the writer of this research Professor Sulaiman Al-Dakhil, may Allah have mercy on him. He mentions that Salem Al Jarba is the grandfather of Mutlaq and Bunayyah Al Jarba. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: I wish Al-Dakhil had cited these numerous proofs?! In any case, this Al-Asi, one of the Sheikhs of Al Jarba, hints at the origin of their journey with this verse from one of his war songs on horses: See your group are the youth of Yemen ... They are not a gathering from a country. The Journey of Al Daigham from the South to the North. For the journey of Al Daigham from the South to the two mountains, there are evidences from the public heritage, and from the texts of historians like the text of Ibn Rasul. About this stage, Dr. Al-Uthaymin said in summary: The Abda clan used to inhabit one of the regions of the south of the Peninsula, then migrated until it settled in Jabal Shammar, and this migration was more than four centuries ago. The princes of the Mountain before Abda's migration were from the Zubaid tribe, so Abda overcame them until they expelled them, and their last leader was Bahij. About that, one of the poets of Shammar said later: Before you, Bahij was driven down by the Sana'is ... From Aqdah which its canal cannot be driven down.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: Abu Abd al-Rahman said: It is understood from this text that the departure of Abda from the south to Jabal Tayy in the north was around the tenth century, and this is also understood from a text by Sheikh Al-Aboudi that will come. It is understood from a text by Ibn Hatim - will come - that their departure was in the middle of the ninth century. If we could connect the lineage of Arar bin Shahwan bin Daigham to Daigham bin Munif whom Ibn Rasul mentioned, we would be able to determine the date of their departure more accurately. If we assume that Arar is Arar bin Shahwan bin Mansour bin Daigham bin Munif, their departure would be in the early eighth Hijri century approximately, because Ibn Rasul who died in the year 694 mentioned that the offspring of Munif Ibn Daigham were still in the south. In light of that, we make the era of each individual of the lineage chain from Arar to Munif thirty years and add the result to seven centuries at the end of which Ibn Rasul died. Regarding their departure, Sheikh Saad bin Junaidil mentioned a poem by Faris Ibn Shahwan Al Daighami, mentioning that he sketched the path of his tribe's migration from their country to Najd, and arranged the stations of their path accurately. He said in it mentioning Al-Quway': And a night in Al-Sirdah, may rain not water it ... Its dry wood stands and its sour plants perished. And I treaded Wadi Al-Quway' intentionally ... I wished it were not for the thirst a land. And a night in Al-Hadba, may its side not flourish ... They packed and left in the resting place blackness. He said in another place: And a poet from Al Daigham said sketching the path of their migration: A night in Al-Qimra and a night in Al-Raka ... And a night in Hazm Al-Hasah distress. And a night we arrived at Masal and Muwaisil ... The faces of the scoops as if they were new. Then he mentioned after these two verses the three verses mentioned above and mentioned in another place that they are by Faris bin Shahwan Al Daighami and his people passed by him on their way of migration to north Najd. My Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser mentioned a modern book - and did not mention its name nor its author's name - that talked about noble horses called Al-Duhm Al-Shahwaniyat. Sheikh Hamad said: It came in this book: Shahwan is Ubaidah i.e. from Qahtan and it was named after its shepherd Shahwan Abu Arar brother of Rashid uncle of Umair. Then he said: And he cited news about these horses and poetry by Shahwan Abu Arar in which came: We have a dwelling between Al-Aflaj and Al-Hasa ... And between Sanaa and Al-Sulayl borders. When they descended seeking prices in the villages ... We descended on like the black clouds. The large Shuwadi supplied us from its crops ... Sacks without firewood or fuel. If the beast of the wild hovered around it, it spent the night hungry ... Inside it like eagles crouching. I wish from the crushing nights perhaps we ... Catch up with some O Abu Rabi' Hamoud. If you don't have armor Najd ... Then drinking with the arms of men is hard. Sheikh Hamad said: He cited months for Arar bin Shahwan and news related to his horses. Sheikh Muhammad Al-Aboudi mentioned a battle between Al Daigham and Sultan Marid, in which Humaidan bin Rashid bin Daigham, cousin of Arar Ibn Shahwan, and Sultan Marid were killed together. Umair bin Rashid said a poem about that starting with: A battle was prepared for us at Abraq Al-Saih ... The absent men wished for it. He determined the era of this poetry to be after the era of the poet Jarir by about nine centuries. Professor Abdullah bin Khalid Al-Hatim mentions that Arar bin Shahwan Al Daigham, grandfather of Al Rashid, princes of Jabal Hail, lived in the year 850 AH. He mentioned a poem for him longing for Najd, from which it is understood that his cousin Umair bin Rashid is present in Najd. From what came in this poem is his saying: Arar says the saying of one who remained standing ... On the house mourning with shedding tears. Little benefit from a ruin whose trace was destroyed ... By the blowing winds the violent storms. But I did not see in it shading tents ... The vicissitudes of the calamities erased them obliterated. Until he said: So no and upon no were it not for wishing is foolishness ... I would stand in Najd safe not afraid.

text: And I find Umair in Al-Udhaibah standing ... On Shalshal the white noble camels. When he saw the affect on his father's face, he left with those who were light with him from his people and slaves. So Shahwan Abda sent Ammar to accompany Faris, and know his direction. When Faris sensed Ammar's accompaniment, he began taking ostrich eggs, so whenever he stopped at a place he showed an egg and filled it with water, and placed dates beside it and buried it under the kneeling place of his she-camel until he stopped at a place near Zafar which Faris named after himself. From the direction of Shahwan dear neighbor. Abdul Jabbar Al-Rawi adds detail mentioning that Shammar killed Bahij the Sheikh of Al-Ubaid so Al-Ubaid migrated to the island of Iraq. Shammar had advised Bahij to enter upon the Sheikhs of Shammar, and reconcile with them but he refused that and said: Bahij bin Dhubyan says proverbs ... And his tear is on the properties without waterfalls. Shammar the sweet ones drove us from our homes ... Clear water and cold water, heals the thirst. And we turned the necks of the camels away from them and went west ... And the eye of Al-Zubaidiyat towards Najd is inclined. If there is no equal to equal an equal ... One cannot sit in the house while the load is tilting. And if the young man's right is not by his arm ... Damn the rule that comes by intercessions. Patient on asceticism despite the badness of their deed ... In lineage there is none like them among tribes. Mean ones if you made them perform Hajj to the Kaaba of satisfaction ... They reward you for it with barren offshoots. Departure of Al Jarba to Iraq

text: Al Jarba are the leaders of Shammar and the heads of the Mountain, and the furthest mention I found of them is about the death of two of them in the year 1100 AH and the year 1103 AH. They left Najd in the year 1205 AH after their defeat before Ibn Saud, so they built their leadership in Iraq and Syria. Hussein Khaz'al said: The general leadership of Shammar was in the Al Jarba family from the Sinjara clan, and Prince Saud Ibn Abdul Aziz evicted them from their homes in the year 1205 AH after he fought them near the city of Hail and Muslat bin Mutlaq was killed. Mutlaq marched from Jabal Shammar to Iraq and the land of Sham, and accompanied Ahmad Pasha Al-Jazzar to Hajj, then settled in the desert of Samawa in Iraq. As for the departure of Al Jarba, Abbas Al-Azzawi mentions that Al Muhammad Al Jarba, princes of Shammar under the leadership of Faris Al Jarba, leaned towards Iraq in the early thirteenth Hijri century. Yusuf Al-Bassam adds detail saying: The former heads of Shammar are known as Al Muhammad and the last of them is Faris Al Jarba. He was nicknamed Al Jarba relative to his mother who was afflicted with smallpox, and became scabby (jarba) as a result of this disease. In the era of Prince Muhammad bin Saud, founder of the first Saudi state, and his son Imam Abdul Aziz, Faris Al Jarba migrated from Jabal Shammar and settled in the desert of Jazira in Iraq between the Tigris and Euphrates, after the rains stopped for a long time and the land became barren. Following the migration of Faris Al Jarba, many of Shammar followed him and settled in Iraq and remain until now, and Al Ali took over the command of Jabal Shammar. Abdul Jabbar Al-Rawi mentioned that Najd was hit by drought, so the Sheikh of the Shammar tribe, Faris, was forced to migrate with forty families of his people, seeking pasture, until he reached the island of Iraq, and settled as a neighbor to the Ubaid tribes, then he mentioned a semi-mythical story, especially regarding the shabbiness of Shammar while it is known among the people of Najd the fame of the northern tribes - especially the Shamamrah - for elegant dress and lavish appearance. He mentioned in another place that the first to migrate from Najd to the Jazira in Iraq was Faris Al Jarba, and that he is the first president of Al Muhammad, then he mentioned his sons and grandsons. He mentioned that Faris was nicknamed Al Jarba relative to his mother, who was afflicted with smallpox, so she was named by it even if she had recovered from this disease. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: There is no harm in citing this story mentioned by Al-Rawi. He said: Najd was hit by drought, forcing the Sheikh of the Shammar tribe at that time, Faris, to migrate with forty tents, seeking pasture, and he went on until he reached the Jazira, and settled as a Qasir "i.e. neighbor" to the Ubaid tribes, who hosted him, and made him a large banquet to which they invited the head of the Tayy and Jubur tribes. The immigrants from Shammar were in shabby clothes, covered in dirt, so the guests were disgusted by them and ate the food reluctantly, and they imagined that these immigrants were from the Suluba or Hutaym tribes, which the Bedouins consider despicable tribes. When Faris, Sheikh of Shammar, felt the disgust that appeared on the faces of the heads of Ubaid, Tayy, and Jubur, he wanted to prove to his hosts that he and his tribe were of such nobility and generosity that they are proverbial, so he decided to reciprocate the banquet with a similar one, and invited the heads of Ubaid, Tayy, and Jubur to eat at his place. However, they hesitated to accept the invitation, believing that these people were not worthy of answering their invitation and attending their banquet. But after hesitation, they answered the invitation reluctantly, and saw the Mansafs - plural of Mansaf which is what food is placed in - filled with food and meat, as he slaughtered camels for them. The Mansafs were of such hugeness that knives were hung on them to help the elderly cut the meat. The hugeness of Mansafs indicates to the Bedouins conclusively the greatness of its owner, therefore they calculated a thousand calculations for these settlers, fearing for themselves, believing that behind these Mansafs were tribes large in number, so they decided to assassinate Faris and his group before his tribes reached him. The banquet of Sheikh Faris was the motive for the three Sheikhs to conspire to kill Faris and his group, as we mentioned previously. However, Faris sensed the conspiracy, so he asked his women to take off their jewelry, and present it to the wives of the three heads as a gift, on condition that they intercede with their husbands to prevent killing him and his aides. They answered the request, and promised them good. When night came, the wives of the leaders of Ubaid, Tayy, and Jubur did not spread the bedding - which among Arabs is a sign from which men infer the occurrence of dangerous matters -, so they were asked about the reason, and they asked for safety for the immigrants

text: So they were given safety, and granted what they wanted, so the bedding was spread. Thus Faris's group was able to settle in the Jazira, and stabilize there. Then Faris cut samples of all the herbs and grasses that grow in the Jazira, and filled a sack with them and sent it with his aides to his tribe in Najd, intending thereby to inform them of the excellent types of grasses for grazing, in the land to which he migrated, urging them to join him. It was not long before the Shammar tribes answered his request, and migrated to him in groups, each group not less than fifty tents, so Shammar multiplied, and what the heads of Ubaid, Tayy, and Jubur feared happened. This matter caused a conflict between them in agreement with Al-Sayih on one side and Shammar on the other, over the land of the Jazira which they settled. A fight broke out lasting ninety days, in which Shammar won, and forced the tribes of Al-Sayih, Al-Ubaid, and Tayy to evacuate their places in the Jazira. Al-Sayih crossed the Tigris, heading towards Hawija, and took it as homes for them. Tayy moved from its place, and made its dwellings west of Sinjar. As for Al-Jubur, they inhabited the Khabur region. Thus the atmosphere cleared for Shammar in the Jazira, and their control over its outskirts and regions was complete, until it came to imposing a type of tax called "Al-Khuwwah" (brotherhood tax) which they took from every tribe settling in their area, and everyone crossing the Jazira was forced to pay it submissively. This "Khuwwah" remained effective, and included all villages neighboring the desert. When the Iraqi government was formed, its regular forces began to combat this "Khuwwah" with all the strength they had, but they could not eradicate it and cut its root completely. Many efforts were made to establish a government center in the Jazira until that was accomplished in the first year of my assuming the reins of the General Police Directorate, as I had previously formed similar in the Shamiya desert before that, and managed to prevent the Khuwwah there. As for "Al-Khuwwah" itself, it is a tax paid by tribes entering the Jazira voluntarily or forcibly, and it is a specific amount of fat and sheep, paid to a specific Sheikh from Shammar every year. "Al-Khuwwah" is also taken from travelers, where they must pay an amount of money for every camel passing through the Jazira, as well as in the villages which pay what grains they owe every season. "Al-Khuwwah" is divided among the Sheikhs of Shammar who each know their share of it. So Sheikh So-and-so takes "Al-Khuwwah" from Al-Hadidin, and the other from Al-Jubur or travelers or from the villages of Mosul or from the merchants' sheep sent to Syria. Thus no one escapes the hands of the collectors of this tax. The Shammar tribes continue to multiply and increase, since the Saudis took over Hail, the capital of Ibn Al-Rashid, where a large number of the Abda clan migrated from Najd to the Jazira in Iraq, and these now form the largest section of Shammar Abda. Among the most famous leaders of Abda migrating to Iraq is Sheikh Iqab Al-Ajl, head of the Al-Ahya division of Abda, and the reason for his migration is Shammar's refusal to recognize a Sheikh or leader in Hail unless he was from Al-Rashid. This, and most tribes of the Hail region, the ancient capital of Ibn Al-Rashid, are from Shammar, at the present time. text: A - It is not unlikely that Al Muhammad were nicknamed Al Jarba because their mother was afflicted with smallpox, but Faris was not the first to be nicknamed so as Yusuf Al-Bassam and Al-Rawi claimed, because I found this nickname used tens of years before the birth of Faris bin Muhammad Al Jarba. The historians of Najd mentioned in the events of the year 1100 AH the killing of Ammar Al Jarba. And they mentioned in the events of the year 1103 AH or 1104 the killing of Muslat Al Jarba. B - Al Jarba did not migrate because of drought, but they migrated because of their defeat before Al Saud as will be explained in the historical events. They did not migrate under the leadership of Faris but migrated under the leadership of his brother Mutlaq, accompanied by his brother Faris and Qurainis. But the Iraqi historians, when they saw that the emirate was in the descendants of Faris, thought that Shammar migrated under his leadership. Faris was a leader before his son Safouk, and perhaps Faris mentioned in the era of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Rashid is one of his grandsons. C - They lived in the island of Iraq (Al-Jazira) between three rivers: the Tigris from the north and east, the Euphrates from the south, and the Khabur from the west. Another section migrated to the Syrian Jazira south of the Euphrates west of the Khabur. The sheikhs of the Sinjara clans in Syria are cousins of Al Muhammad and their count is in Abda according to the correct famous opinion. D - Since Al Muhammad migrated, they remained there a settled stay. As for their clans, they are still nomadic between Iraq and Najd, except that their close relatives remained there, just as the majority of Abda remained there also, except for those who did not prefer returning to the island of Iraq after their return to Najd. Regarding the story of their return to Najd after their departure to the Jazira, we find two indications: The first: In the year 1224 AH after Shammar's defeat before Al-Zafir in the island of Iraq, they wrote to Imam Saud, so he permitted them and they appeared to Najd. The second: In the year 1231 AH after the killing of their leader Bunayyah bin Qurainis, they evacuated the Jazira and settled with their people in the Mountain. E - Yusuf Al-Bassam mentioned in the text mentioned above that Faris Al Jarba migrated from Jabal Shammar, and settled in the desert of Jazira in Iraq, after the rains stopped for a long time. Following Faris's migration, many of Shammar followed him and settled in Iraq during the era of Imam Muhammad bin Saud and his son Abdul Aziz. He described Faris as the last of Al Muhammad to have leadership in Najd. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Their journey was only at the end of the era of Imam Abdul Aziz as his son Saud expelled them, and were it not for him saying "and settled", I would have said: It is possible that Shammar migrated with Faris due to drought in the era of Muhammad bin Saud then migrated as evacuees in the era of Saud.

text: F - It is known and famous among historians that the leadership of the Mountain belonged to Al Jarba, Bedouin and settled, then to Al Ali, then to Al Rashid, but Dr. Al-Uthaymin refuses that. He said commenting on Al-Rihani: Perhaps it is more accurate if it was said: That Al Jarba was the leader of the Bedouin of Jabal Shammar, because the emirate of the settled people of the Mountain "Hail" belonged to Al Ali before the region joined Al Saud. The Doctor did not approve of "Hogarth's" opinion in saying that Abdullah Ibn Rashid was a leader of the Shammar tribes. And he did not approve of Al-Fakhiri's saying about Abdullah bin Rashid "Head of the Shammar Bedouin". Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Wherever the Mountain is mentioned absolutely, it refers to its inhabitants from Bedouin and settled. The leadership of Al Jarba for the Mountain is a leadership of all Shammar tribes, like the leadership of Ibn Rabi'an for example for all Otaiba tribes and like the leadership of Ibn Hadi for all Qahtan tribes. This does not prevent the existence of an emirate for the specific settled people, and that Al Jarba do not care about the specific settled people, except that the bond between the settled and the Bedouin is raids, campaigns, and kinship in terms of lineage "or loyalty in most cases". Therefore, the settled people follow the banner of Al Jarba. Then the leadership of the Mountain, Bedouin and settled, shifted from the traditional Sheikh of all Bedouin, who is Al Jarba, to the Emir of the specific settled people, who is Ibn Ali. It is not a condition for this shift to be recognized in the custom of Bedouin sheikhdom or for the Shammar tribes to be submissive to this shift. Rather, this shift was done by the ruler from Al Saud, for he is the one who chose that the leadership of the Mountain, Bedouin and settled, belong to Ibn Ali, then to Ibn Rashid, such that whoever deviated from this obedience from the Shammar tribes is considered a rebel. There are evidences for this: Among them is that the emirate of Al Ali did not precede the era of Al Saud as Dr. Al-Uthaymin said, for I clarified in my talk about Al Ali that the Shammar tribe submitted to the Call before the year 1178 AH based on a text from "Lam' Al-Shihab". And among them is that Sheikh Iqab bin Ajl migrated from Hail because Shammar refused to recognize a Sheikh or leader in Hail unless he was from Al Rashid, so this is proof that Ibn Rashid is the leader of all his Bedouin. And among them is that the settled people of Hail fought Mutlaq Al Jarba and his Bedouin and wrote to Imam Abdul Aziz informing him that Mutlaq broke the pledge, so these events indicate that the Emir of the settled people has an official leadership over the Bedouin which is demanded and fought for. And among them is that the Shammar tribes present in Najd participated in the raids of Al Saud, and we did not see the banner tied to any of the Shammar Sheikhs, but the leadership was for Ibn Ali or Ibn Rashid. Dr. Shafiq Al-Kamali said commenting on a text of "The Encyclopedia of Islam" in the article Bilad al-Arab regarding Tayy and Zubaid paying "Al-Khuwwah" to Shammar: As for not paying "Al-Khuwwah", it is correct, and "Al-Khuwwah" was replaced when Faris Al Jarba entered the Jazira by marriage alliance, as he married his son Safouk to Amsha, the daughter of the Sheikh of Tayy, and that was around the year 1225 AH. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Perhaps the histories of Hijaz reveal to us the history of Al Daigham, for I saw Arar mentioning the Sharifs in his poetry, just as I saw Al-Isami mentioning a battle between the Sharifs and Shammar and also mentioning that Sharif Idris, who was rivaled by his cousin Muhsin, died in Jabal Shammar and was buried in Yatib in the year 1033. Mustafa Murad Al-Dabbagh mentions that it is possible that the village of Jarba in the district of Jenin in Palestine and Jarba in eastern Jordan are attributed to the Jarba tribes of Iraqi Shammar that settled there and imprinted their name on them. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Note that Al Muhammad are from Al Jarba and not the reverse, and that Al Muhammad does not include Al Jarba but is limited to the descendants of Muhammad bin Salim Al Jarba. Due to the sovereignty of Al Jarba, the Bedouin of Shammar in Iraq became called Shammar Al Jarba. Al Jarba remained remembered by the people of Najd, poets headed towards them and received their grants, and their cousins in northern Najd sought their help. Conversely, there were found in Shammar of the Jazira those who longed for Najd. Here is a poet from Shammar, complaining about the Shia of Iraq and longing for Hail, saying: O help of the one who saw you, O Barzan ... And slept in your embrace happy. O help of the one who left you, O Barghouth ... And the separation of Abadah is upon me. From the Historical Events of Al Jarba

text: A - In the year 1205 AH, Sharif Ghalib bin Musa'id of Mecca equipped his brother Abdul Aziz with an army in which some Bedouins participated, to attack Diriyah, then Ghalib went out with a great army to reinforce his brother. Then when they were defeated after besieging the town of Al-Sha'ra, Saud bin Abdul Aziz began raiding the tribes that rebelled and joined the Sharif. Among these were Mutayr and Shammar, they were at the water known as Al-Udwa belonging to Shammar, near Hail, and their leader was Hisan Iblis. Imam Saud headed to them in this place, defeated them, and their leader Masoud "Hisan Iblis" and Samrah "?" the famous leader of Al-Abiyat from Mutayr, and Abu Hulaiba from Mutayr were killed. This battle was at the end of Dhu al-Hijjah of this year. However, these people after their defeat mobilized the rest of their tribes, and sent to Saud inviting him to battle, and warning him of their march towards him. He was in his place at Al-Udwa, dividing the spoils. So he stood firm for them after they reached him under the leadership of Muslat bin Mutlaq Al Jarba, who vowed to penetrate Saud's "marquee" with his horse. Muslat loosened the rein of his horse to fulfill his vow, but Saud's people snatched him after a man hit him with a stick used to roast disk bread, knocking him off his steed, and then he was killed and his followers were defeated. When they came to him, they approached with their camels tied together, so Saud and his army stood firm for them, and fired upon them and their camels with bullets. When they were defeated, they left their camels tied with ropes, so Saud captured eleven thousand camels from them, and more than a thousand sheep, and followed their tracks for two days taking money and killing men. Mutlaq Al Jarba, father of Muslat, was of the opinion to wait before attacking Al Saud, after their first defeat at Al-Udwa. It is said: This poem by Muslat Al Jarba was said on this occasion: I climbed the heads of the lofty watchtowers ... A tall high cairn standing upright. I dragged a voice like the wolf dragged ... I feel my conscience jumping from my ribs. My fear is of those whose heads are like quivers ... And a sword cuts on other than the joints. When my wishes became like slaves ... With booties in our right hands we prick him. It is better to be patient and make patience beautiful with goodness ... This life, all of its father is squeezing. And the free one, when the claws close on him ... Is bound to jump from the house of humiliation. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The last verse is an announcement of evacuation from Jabal Shammar, and evacuation was not in Muslat's intention. It is more likely that this poetry is by Mutlaq Al Jarba, father of Muslat, and this is what actually happened. After Shammar's defeat, and the killing of Muslat, Shammar migrated under the leadership of Mutlaq Al Jarba to Iraq, settled in the Jazira region, and gained strong influence there. Ibn Sanad said in his emotional literary style: He has days, among them Al-Udwa for Saud bin Abdul Aziz against him, and on that day his son Muslat was killed, and he was a brave lion who fought that day until he stopped every patrol, and entertained every spear and sword, how not when Mutlaq his father is that brave, and Muhammad his grandfather whom bombs avoided. As for Mutlaq, on that day he defeated the battalions, and quenched every spear and cutting sword with the blood of the knights: A people if they fought are lions of the thicket ... And if they gave are seas of generosity. O eye, if they die, then generosity has died ... So be generous with your tears for them in sadness. They waded into the war with sharp swords and strong horses ... Lean-bellied, heading for the army of "Su'ud". So the brave ones dispersed from him as if they were ... Ostriches fleeing from the roar of lions. The lion Mutlaq met them ... So they hung onto the tail of every young camel. When the lowlands and highlands narrowed on Saud, Ibn Hadhdhal betrayed, so Mutlaq had no room, so he retreated on his heels while fighting that clamorous army. Whenever he attacked his knights ... They fled from him like a sheep from a lion. They did not see a calamity but saw ... Fleeing from it, even if it was a lion.
