text: So they remained with him in attack and retreat, and striking with every sharp male sword, until they tired of striking, so they returned with a losing deal, and he and his cousins survived, and the traitor returned with his disgrace and sin, so he settled his men in the desert of Iraq, until his life became green and pure. I found in the notebooks of Sheikh Mandil these verses by Mutlaq's wife mourning Muslat and his father: I groaned a groan of one whose tooth the pliers pulled ... Who endured the pulling attracting from where. Upon you, O protector of the camels, Tahmaz ... The groups of Arabs clamored missing him. Eqab came to us and separated the free and the hawk ... And became with the hunter of bustards his mound. The tear from my eye comes single and in pairs ... And greyness appeared in my forelock before its time. The author of "Lam' Shihab" said: Then the Arabs of the Sharif who were taking refuge with him from the Bedouins of Najd dispersed from him returning to the outskirts of Najd. Qahtan turned to Tathlith, Otaiba to the wilderness of Mecca like Rukbah and what follows it. As for Mutayr, they turned to the land of Shammar, and agreed with Mutlaq Al Jarba, and all the Bedouins of Shammar who are in the Mountain, and a war occurred between them and the people of the villages in the Mountain. So the people of the Mountain sent to Abdul Aziz bin Saud that this Mutlaq Al Jarba broke the pledge, and Mutayr took refuge with him, so today we fight him. At that time the Sheikh of Mutayr was Husain bin Watban, a brave man. When Abdul Aziz heard this news, he sent his son Saud with an army to them, with him some of Anazah, who were opponents to Mutayr, and with him also the Bedouins of Al-Arid: Subai' and Al-Ajman. This march was his first support to Al Saud, and the fame of his affair in the Arabian Peninsula, then he gained great reputation. This army reached five thousand "infantry" men and eight hundred horsemen. He attacked Arabs called Al-Bara'isa from Mutayr in the morning, and their leader was named Saud? nicknamed Hisan Al-Shaytan, or Hisan Iblis, and he is the one who nicknamed himself with this nickname, and he is a counted brave man, and with him two hundred horsemen of his company. They fought Saud and a number of his horsemen were killed and Hisan Iblis and his children and his brother's children were killed, and his houses and sheep were taken, and their camels were absent in the desert. After this, the matter intensified on Mutlaq Al Jarba, and Husain Al-Dawish, and the world narrowed on them and they were at a water called "Yatib" eight hours from Hail. So they came attacking Saud, and camped wanting to engage in war with him. Wars occurred between them and Saud, so he drove first in their faces until he pushed their gatherings with it, then followed them with horses and men. A son of Mutlaq Al Jarba named Sultan was killed, and those Bedouins were defeated, and their number was many. He took their wealth and killed who he killed and captured who he captured, and the total of their wealth is countless. So Mutlaq Al Jarba evacuated to Iraq from that day. B - In Ramadan of the year 1212 AH, Imam Saud bin Abdul Aziz fought many Arabs from several tribes under the leadership of Mutlaq bin Muhammad Al Jarba in Wadi Al-Ubayyid near Samawa in Iraq. No one could stand before Mutlaq's attacks. Ibn Bishr and Ibn Sanad mentioned that, and Qurainis, Mutlaq's brother, was killed. Ibn Sanad said - as I copied from the papers of Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser: Saud bin Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Saud raided in the year 1212 the outskirts of Bani Al-Munfaq, so he attacked the village known as Umm Al-Abbas in the morning, killed many of its people and those around it, looted and burned, then returned. Hamoud was in the desert, when the news reached him he strove in marching to catch him, as he caught him. After Saud returned and reached the outskirts of Najd, he turned and raided in that year of his the desert of Iraq. Mutlaq bin Muhammad Al Jarba was camping in the desert of Iraq. When Saud attacked them in the morning, whoever fled fled and whoever stood stood. Mutlaq Al Jarba fought Saud's army, so the horsemen attacked time after time, whenever he attacked a battalion he defeated it, so the brave ones deviated from fighting him. It was from Allah Almighty which cannot be repelled that he attacked them in one of his attacks and his horse stumbled on a sheep, so he fell from his horse's back and was killed, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - and his killing was considered by Saud one of the greatest victories except that he wished to capture him instead of killing him.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: C - In the year 1231 AH, the battle took place between the Pasha of Iraq and several tribes under the leadership of Bunayyah bin Qurainis bin Muhammad Al Jarba, and with him Faris bin Muhammad, and the Pasha had expelled them from Iraq. So these tribes were defeated after the killing of their leader Bunayyah in an incident similar to the killing of his uncle Mutlaq bin Muhammad, that is, two horsemen caught up with him, so he sensed them or they called him to duel, so he pulled the rein of his steed a terrible pull to turn it towards them, so the mare fell on her head and hands, and fell on her back, so he became under the saddle and the mare over him, so he was caught and killed. Perhaps the reason for this is what happened in the year 1228 AH, which is that As'ad bin Sulaiman Pasha feared Abdullah Pasha the ruler of Baghdad and fled to Al-Munfaq. When Hamoud bin Thamir the leader of Al-Munfaq refused and after fighting, Shammar sided with Al-Munfaq, and betrayed Abdullah Pasha, so the Iraqi soldiers were defeated. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The common people in Najd pronounce Al Jarba like this "Al Jarba" without Hamza, due to the heaviness of the Hamza letter on the pronunciation of the common people. Ibn Sanad said: In the year one thousand two hundred and thirty-one of the Hijrah, to him (the number of what knowledge encompassed, and what ability attached to of possibilities, Bunayyah bin Qurainis Al Jarba was killed, and his head was brought to the Vizier Sa'id. Know that Bunayyah crossed from the Jazira to west of the Euphrates, when Sa'id Pasha assumed the ministry of Baghdad, due to the grudges between his uncle Faris and Al Ubaid, especially their emir Qasim bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Shawi Al-Ubaidi. Sa'id Pasha had entrusted the reins of most of his affairs to him. Due to what was between Faris and the mentioned, he did not settle in the Jazira, so he descended with his tribe on Khuza'ah, in that year, to measure grain. Al-Duray'i Al-Anazi Al-Ruwaili - with Damma on Ra and Fatha on Waw and Lam after it Ya of attribution - tracked his trace and descended near him, and sent to Hamoud bin Thamir, asking for help, so he mobilized with the horsemen of his tribe to help Al-Duray'i, due to the coalition between them. Also the army of the Vizier Sa'id went out, their elder Qasim Ibn Shawi, and with him Uqayl - with Damma on Ain and Fatha on Qaf and Sukun on the lower double-dot Ya - and they are soldiers for the Vizier. So the war stood on a leg and the horsemen defended. It was decreed upon him in one of his attacks that a bullet hit him, so he fell from the back of his horse, may Allah have mercy on him and us - and I heard him attributing himself to Tayy the known tribe to which Hatim bin Abdullah bin Sa'd Al-Ta'i and his son Adi bin Hatim Al-Ta'i the venerable Companion are attributed. This is a literary text, in an emotional style I copied from the papers of my Sheikh Hamad Al-Jasser quoting from "Matali' Al-Su'ud bi Tib Akhbar Al-Wali Dawud" by Uthman bin Sanad. Ibn Sanad said: "D" And in the year 1237 AH, the governor of Kerman had sent about a thousand of his soldiers for provisions from those homelands, so Safouk Al Jarba met them, and entertained them with stabbing and striking, and watered them punishment instead of fresh water, and made them gulp bitterness and colocynth with swords, so he killed many of them, and the rest were between defeated and captured. Then he said after a long speech related to Dawud Pasha: Several trustworthy people told me that Safouk bin Faris Al Jarba raided Ibn Al-Shah, and crossed Diyala, with horsemen from his tribe, until he was in sight of Ibn Al-Shah's army. The army's horsemen rode when they saw him and attacked him, so he lured them until they crossed Diyala, and were far from it. Then he and those from his tribe and from the Romans turned on them, so the Persian horsemen retreated, and the horsemen of Shammar followed them, and killed those they caught, and brought their horses and loot - and praise and gratitude be to Allah -. More than one person told me that this is different from the first one mentioned by the Turkish historian. text: Before detailing each section of these sections, we present an introduction about the famous family to which the reins of the supreme leadership in Shammar Al Jarba were cast. Those who led this tribe are "Al Muhammad", and as they multiplied until they became a group, indeed a large tribe, we found no escape from mentioning those who belong to this house since its first inception until today, praising their most famous leaders in the past and present: The first who migrated from Najd to the Jazira in Iraq was Faris Al Jarba, so he is the first leader of Al Muhammad, Sheikhs of Shammar in the Jazira. Faris left a group named Al Faris, and from these Safouk became famous, and from the children of Safouk Farhan Pasha the famous became famous. Farhan Pasha left many children, divided into four branches, each branch attributed to its mother "i.e. to one of Farhan Pasha's four wives", and these branches are: Al-Durrah, Al-Jaz'ah, Al-Sarhah, and Al-Bashat. First Branch - Al-Durrah estimated with their freedmen at five hundred houses, and most famous of them are Al Abdul Aziz, Al Faisal, and Al Shallal. From Al Abdul Aziz emerged and headed all Shammar tribes Sheikh "Ajil Al-Yawar bin Abdul Aziz bin Farhan Pasha" may Allah have mercy on him, and the leadership is still in his offspring. Second Branch - Al-Jaz'ah estimated with their freedmen at 500 houses also, and most famous of them are Al-Asi, Al-Jarallah, and Al Mijwel. Al-Asi lived "120" years, and became Sheikh of all Shammar then the Sheikhdom devolved to his son Al-Hadi in his era, while he was alive then Al-Hadi was killed, and the Sheikhdom devolved to Daham head of the Shammar tribes residing in Syria now. Third Branch - Al-Sarhah estimated with their freedmen at 100 houses, and their most famous leaders are Mutlaq, Hayis, Thuwaini, Abdul Muhsin, and Sultan. Fourth Branch - Al-Bashat named after the Pashas, because they did not leave Farhan Pasha's house until his death, and are estimated with their freedmen at "50" houses, and their dwellings are now in Al-Farhaniyah near Balad "a district belonging to Samarra district in Baghdad governorate", and their most famous leaders are Al-Humaidi to whom the Sheikhdom of Shammar devolved in the Ottoman era, and Mizar and Bandar, and they have died, and Ahmad and Zaid, and they are alive and sustained. There are others besides these attributed to Al Muhammad, such as: Al Amr: estimated with their freedmen at "300" houses, most prominent of them is Zaid Al-Amr. Al Zaidan: estimated with their freedmen at "300" houses also. Al Fahd: estimated with their freedmen at "30" houses, and most famous of them is Sattam Al-Fahd, and the Sheikhdom of Shammar was not entrusted to any of them. The Poet Ibn Hattab. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Among Al Jarba who did not migrate to the Jazira are Al-Sa'dun and Al Sarah in Al-Jawf, among them Al Salman from Al Hubub from Al Sarah. From Al Sarah is the poet Ghalib bin Hattab, from his poetry is his saying addressing Sharidah, the servant of his host: Oh how happy is he who climbed the head of Al-Faridah ... And saw Al-Tawil and saw the nose of Al-Adhari. Better for me than facing Sharidah ... Making the camels of the brave kneel at the palace of Ibn Zarra. And his father is the one Ubaid Al-Rashid means by his saying: O who gives me glad tidings of Khulaif and Hattab ... The glad tidings of Pharaoh about Moses and Aaron. I found in Sheikh Mindil's notebooks these verses by Hattab, and he mentioned that he said them while in Ibn Rashid's prison: O those successful in good, O people of the camels ... May happiness be in their throats when you walk. With Al-Naqib call the path of the camels ... And tomorrow afternoon at Al-Laqait you will land. You will find Nasir like the free of the imported ... A den and the age of dens never fail. You will find a cup of coffee settling ... An increase on what they put in the Mansafs. If only for the one who saw those ruins ... In an hour where every cursed one attends. From the poetry of Ghalib bin Hattab is a poem Abu Muhammad Al-Baza'i told me, may Allah have mercy on him, in which he says: O Allah, O Who is above us, Exalted ... We and those who hope for Your reward beside us. We without Your request did not want ... Even if our provision came, it would not please us.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: O white women, count the veils upon us ... Count your veils and here are our beards. Put the twisted gold in my hands ... And adorn yourselves with our swords, O women. No return for the camels of the loads carrying us ... And we upon us their anger, what is wrong with us. After summoning the tribes we were taken ... Today if a fool comes he would take us. And after treading on tribes we were trodden ... Today with feet everyone trod on us. And Abu Muhammad Al-Baza'i told me these verses by Hattab: You did not obey my advice when I was in Al-Saqfiyah ... You say: Here and I say Here. After we were its glory and countryside ... Today we wait for a seat in our lunch. Oh my groan, the groan of a weak camel ... For homes we knew behind us. If crying relieves we would have cried "Munifah" ... The garden which our enemies legislated in. Today the dates of "Al-Kasb" are a marvel to me ... After we used to eat the tails of our sweets. As for the poem which includes: Fie on the world if we rejoiced in it ... To return in it from our passion we deviated. Ibn Khamis attributed it once to Hattab, and once to Barghash Ibn Zaid bin Uray'ir, and Ibn Saihan attributed it to Nimr bin Adwan. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: The verified is that it belongs to Ibn Uray'ir, but there is a poem on its meter and rhyme by Murkhan bin Dabis - father of Ibn Samhan - Al-Murkhan from the people of Al-Jawf in which he says: No return for us when your turn we were patient ... What makes you panic from our turn when it came. You were deceived by a time for Al-Duray'i we were unaware ... With trumpet or with purity it did not guard us. We when the smoke rises and we spread ... With the hemp rope the sucking we dip our buckets. Without planting not with its rise we trade ... And it was not said: The door closed on who came to us. O father of emergencies do not reveal our news ... A fault is your language, and a fault we are our language. We covered your nakedness and your widow ... And refused upon honor the arms of our beards. And from the poetry of Ghalib bin Sarah is his saying replying with it to Ubaid Al-Ali Al-Rashid: If you come to us O Ubaid we open the door for you ... We stand and indeed your group enters. In Al-Jawf you find in it Khulaif and Hattab ... They are not a group of weaklings fleeing from you. O Ubaid what is your intent Zakat and deputies ... These are with a judge but O Ubaid you cover. O Ubaid since you are a companion to Hattab ... And the molasses at Husain is scooped with a vessel. Mutlaq bin Muhammad Al Jarba. Among their most prominent notables in the Jazira and Syria is Mutlaq bin Muhammad bin Salim Al Jarba, who led those who migrated with him to Iraq from the Shammaris accompanied by his brother Faris after his brother Qurainis bin Muhammad and his son Muslat bin Mutlaq were killed. Ibn Sanad said in his emotional style towards this noble house: This Mutlaq is from the noble Arabs, of deep-rooted lineage and noble descent, from the brave knights, whose courage no human doubts, he has stances in which the spear and the sword testify for him, and incidents in which the enemy and the friend acknowledged his bravery, and as for his generosity he is the sea speak about it without harm, and as for his morals they are gentler than the north wind and more fragrant than lavender, and as for his house it is the Kaaba of the needy and the corner of the seekers, he combined bravery and generosity in his cloak, such that the tongues of his peers called out: He is the unique flag, and the Shammari whose generosity has no limit, and by Allah he incapacitated those after him from the leaders of the desert, with noble deeds described only as apparent and visible: O sea do not boast of your tide and stop ... From matching a Hatimi Shammari. What settled in his palms is divided among ... All people, their rich and the poor. No feat rose but narrated ... Its raised from him the tongue of ages. For his courtyard is a shelter for the fearful fugitive ... And his gift is a magnet for the insolvent poor.

text: And he said about his migration: Then the Arab ambition called him to ascend the high positions, so he marched from Iraq to the Levant, and headed with Ahmad Al-Jazzar to the Sacred House. Then when he completed his rituals he returned to Iraq from Mecca fighting with fingers and spears, those innovators not with the tongue, so he remained in the desert of Iraq with his command obeyed, his mention spread in the lowlands and highlands, no proverb is struck except by his bravery and generosity, and no fugitive seeks refuge except in the courtyard of his sanctuary, and nothing is sought except his palms, and nothing is kissed except his right hand, until the arrow of death hit him and he ascended a martyr to the Abode of Peace. Then Ibn Sanad composed this poem in praise of Mutlaq: The high spears and thin blades wept him ... Since the tolerant one disappeared from him in the grave. Aja wept from what grieved it and Masal ... And the deserts clamored with wailing. For the calamity of a man sharp cutting broad ... Patient when calamities intensified on him. Forgiving, generous, releasing the palm with dew ... As if his hands for gifts were keys. A noble self-made man from the group who ... Their pride is like the sun white clear. Swords, stalwarts, great ones, examples ... Support for the poor, rains, tolerant. To the most abundant of them in tide and most famous in height ... And greatest in worth the calamities were destined. So a brave one from him was deposited in the belly of the earth ... Dear to him are a Mashrafi sword and a swimmer horse. He never closed his eyes one day on a mote ... Nor desired except what the blades desire. A youth who waded into every battalion if ... None waded it except the strong lion. An arrow was destined for him so it dwelled him in the earth ... So here is every region in it a mourner and wailer. So Salma almost collapsed because of him, and become desolate ... Pastures in its sides and grazing lands. O Mutlaq the Bedouins have no joy after you ... For here he is from excessive gloom frowning. And here he is no rain is sought, nor tent ... Is built, nor a cloud pouring with generosity. And no domes were built over the hills ... And no smeller smelled the scents of dew from him. Since you died generosity said: Here I am dead by the death of a man whom a goer and comer weep. Saddles were not put on horses were it not for you for a raid ... Nor would apraiser have loved poetry were it not for you. Nor would the litters have followed a master like you ... Attributed to the heights by the noble chiefs. And life did not please after losing you one ... Were it not for your dew the calamities would have surrounded him. There is no heart but burning with sorrow for you ... And no eye but in it flowing and shedding. Tayy attributed you to the noble bright ones ... Smiling of face, pouring of palm, giver. Jealous over the female neighbors not looking ... At them nor exposing a secret from them. So from you and in your descriptions is hoped ... The blissful dew and elegies and praises are found sweet. If you protected with swords a chased one ... He is avoided by what the predators fear. And he became in a shade of security lush ... Guarded by a swordsman and archer and spearman. As if you are clouds for the seekers ... Remaining while they are the morning and evening clouds. The Arabs ceased not to hope to catch up with you ... And are not like winds in the breeze the fans. And where from the heads in virtue are legs? And where from the buckets are the pouring clouds?

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: Were it not for you the Bedouins and the wilderness would not be joyous nor would the strong horses be joyous for the raid. May a cloud lingering heavy and pouring water ... A grave you became in it from satisfaction. And may there cease not from you one whose courtyard is sought ... And a fugitive and praiser covers him in the calamity. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: In Mutlaq's life his brother Qurainis was killed in the year 1212 and his son Muslat in the year 1205. Bunayyah bin Qurainis Al Jarba. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: I do not know when Mutlaq died, and the leadership was taken over after him by his brother Faris, and he had grown old and was the Sheikh of "Al-Shaddad" (authority) and the leader of battles in the era of Faris his nephew Bunayyah bin Qurainis Ibn Muhammad. Ibn Sanad said: And Bunayyah - with Damma on Ba, Fatha on Nun, Tashdid on Ya and Ha of femininity - is one of the knights of the Arabs and their generous ones, and he had like his uncle Faris in the days of the Vizier Ali Pasha great pomp and precedence. And this Bunayyah almost rivals in bravery Faris Al-Na'amah, and Muhattim Ibn Al-Arqam Dha Al-Ghazala, and as for generosity he is the rain nay the vast sea, and as for protecting the neighbor with every sharp cutting sword, he is at the peak of it, and people only follow his example in it, and as for lowering his gaze from his female neighbors, it is a matter in which his rivalry is not coveted. As for lineage he is from the houses of the Arabs. Attributed to high honor by Banu Thu'al Lions of the thicket and chiefs of the first leaders. The dwellers of the desert over hills And the builders of houses of glory with spears. The slaughterers of camels for guests their slaughtering Lions of the den, with what they drew of blades. And the protectors of the neighbor with swords shining Between the two armies and the quivering spears. Ibn Sanad said: And for what Bunayyah had of generosity and bravery and high fame and for the affection between me and him I eulogized him extemporaneously then he mentioned this poem: He died so for my tear on the cheeks is pouring ... A lion whom the Mashrafi sword wails. A noble of two lineages from those who ... Their pride is like the two luminaries shining. Over the likes of them weeps a stranger thrown ... By black calamities and hardships. And a night traveler in a desert destitute of provision ... Guided to them by lights and cattle. And the fierce war weeps them and a strong horse ... Lean like the wolf of the desert swimming. As if they are for virtue among people eyes ... And for glory a heart and for generosities a spirit. They are the lighters of fire in the desert for guests And for the star in the winter night setting. And a white Shammari I wept ... Attributed to the original origin forgiving. And magnificent as for his grandfather he is Hatim ... And Sa'd and as for his tide it is pouring. As if the natural dew accompanied his spirit Since Noah settled in the honored Ark. So O their generosity if you weep them you weep masters ... With their spreading the cloak of pride smells fragrant. And weep those who were by the melting of their blood ... Treating ulcers that were incurable and wounds. Knights arriving with the step their whites ... And for the lions from the shine of swords approaching. I wept and continued weeping a noble one ... With whom I used to suppress the lords of discord. Bunayyah and the chief who ceased not with him ... Trotting to the blood of wars fan. The pouring of the armored ones' blood as if it is ... A evening drink for him in his attack and a morning drink. I lost with him the full moon that sank since he died ... Seas having from his palms pouring. So I wailed and the flocks of tears as if they were ... Clouds, and the bereaved of the noble ones wails.

text: And I am not fulfilling for him some of his love Even if I last as long as the pigeon wails I wail. He mentioned that he was killed in the year 1231 AH and his head was brought to the Vizier Sa'id. Al-Marik mentioned that Al-Ashmal is Bunayyah Al Jarba, brother of Mutlaq Al Jarba, and Al-Marik mentioned this commenting on Al-Harbid's saying: Sheikh Mandil Al-Fuhayd mentioned to me that the one who killed Bunayyah was Al-Ruwalah in the migration of Anazah against Al Jarban taking revenge for the famous robbery of Hissah. She is Hissah bint Al-Humaidi bin Hadhdhal. That is because Bunayyah when he knew of the coming of Al-Ruwalah sent asking for help from Al Sa'dun, although there were revenges between him and Al Sa'dun, so they promised him to come out for negotiation with them, so he went out safe with no more than forty, so they betrayed him. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Then I found in Mandil's notebooks a summary: "A battle occurred between Bunayyah Al Jarba, one of the known Sheikhs of Shammar, and the Turks, led by Nasir Al-Ashqar Al-Sa'dun in the days of previous wars. It was said: That Bunayyah did not have anyone of his people with him during the battle so his horse stumbled with him and he was killed. And it was said: That his head was cut off from his body, and brought to Ibn Sa'dun's council, and placed in a high place near the fire, with the intention of the arrogance of seizing or wondering at his bravery. There was a Shammari man neighbor to the people of Al-Sa'dun, I do not know his name, except that he is Fidaghi from Sinjara. When he saw the head of Bunayyah Al Jarba, he recognized his facial features, so he was affected and stood up and sat near it, and began combing his mustache with his hand or stick and saying: The owner of this face with the awe and great status does not deserve this. Then he said verses of poetry praising Bunayyah and insinuating against Ibn Sa'dun and left to his house. After that some of those present in the council said to Ibn Sa'dun: Did you hear the Shammari's speech? He said: No, so he sent someone to bring him. When the messenger arrived there he asked about him and was told: Sleeping in the Raffa, and after approaching him to wake him he found him dead. Unfortunately, I did not find the verses he said before leaving the council, despite my search for them and asking many narrators. These are verses from a poem said by Abta eulogizing her father Bunayyah after he was killed in this battle, saying in it: He gathered his ropes then collected and carried it ... And she arched from the much retreating and advancing. Condolences O wolf of the captives his fright ... Yes by Allah O people of horses a horseman. How often he gave from every thoroughbred a progeny ... Racing the raid of horses lifted tail. How often you drank from the sweetness of his pots ... In the time of hardship he cheapens for you the dear wealth. How often he pushed away with the sword from a difficult matter ... And how often he slapped away from you everyone who aggressed. No one pierced his spear, nor anyone bent to him ... No battle happened with him that pleased the mind. *** And Al-Ashmal who is from his wishes the repetitions ... And Mutlaq able in the fresh pool. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: It is Bunayyah bin Qurainis, and Mutlaq is his uncle. Bunayyah bin Qurainis Al Jarba is the one who ordered washing the horse of Al-Wudaihi three times with soap, because Basri Al-Wudaihi fled on it escaping in a war of Al Jarba with Al-Ruwalah. On the occasion of killing Bunayyah, a poet from Al-Sadid from Shammar said, boasting of killing Bunayyah, and referring to the aggression of Al Jarba against Al-Sadid: We marched from "Al-Shimbal" to the palace of "Shallal" ... Two months, and the third we slaughtered Bunayyah. Oh yes by Allah O people of horses a horseman ... And my condolences to his descendants the pride of Shammar. This is the reward of the one who sold us for Ibn Hadhdhal ... We brought his brain to the Pashas a gift. And this is a poet from Al-Burqa' from Shammar living in Aqdah he and his group under the mercy of its Emir Ibn Fawzan Al-Dosari saying: Whoever wants "Aqdah" and the pleasure of its growth ... Let him be patient even if he is stabbed in the side. And whoever does not want "Aqdah" let him leave its front ... Let him head for "Bunayyah" with groups groaning. Meaning Bunayyah bin Qurainis. Safouk bin Faris Al Jarba

text: As for his uncle Faris, he died in the year 1233 AH, so the leadership was taken over after his son Safouk bin Faris bin Muhammad bin Salim. Ibn Sanad said: And Safouk this - with Fatha on the neglected Sad and Fa followed by a Sukun Waw and Qaf - is originally the inaccessible of mountains, and the soft of bows, and the smooth high rock, its plural is Sufq like Kutub. This generous one was named with it, and the Hatimi who became rich with his gift the destitute. By Allah he is unique, in his generosity about which the tongue of description is short. No wonder the youth follows the footsteps of his fathers, and his fathers there is none of them but is proverbial in his generosity: They are the noble ones so ask about them for they are Who are asked when the crises intensify. Whoever settles in their courtyard as a guest saw in them ... Lions if they collided clouds if they were generous. No neighbor of theirs was wronged by time nor did they forsake ... A client, nor were they heavy in nature nor frowned. No night traveler saw a fire of hospitality and headed for it ... Except that its raiser until it is seen is them. If their guest desired their souls they would grant So let their guest fear Allah regarding souls. Their leader did not lead except with a drawn sword ... Its dye is clot from who transgressed and blood. And by their right the fire of an enemy did not light ... Except that its lighter are their swords with them. No Arab boasted except their youth surpassed ... With every virtue their elders surpassed with. Fond of what their fathers were accustomed to ... Before weaning the newborn loves dew. As if they for the hospitality of guests were created And for stabbing for the lions of the forest colliding. Served but in their councils ... For every guest by hastening hospitality are servants. Were it not for them no Bedouin or hill would flourish Nor would "Aja" and "Al-Nir" and "Al-Alam" flourish. Nor litters in the desert accustomed ... To the stabbing of knights from them a cutting sword. Heavy if attributed then to the generous ones from Thu'al ... And the givers when others were stingy. And the carriers of the longest spear So the lions know that the spearmen are them. And the dwellers in Najd every hill ... The rugged grounds and hills fell short of it. They did not ride the donkey in Bedouin or settled life But strong horses, from them the bay and the black. High proud so they did not pay to a king ... Tribute nor did injustice befall their female neighbors. Their neighbor does not complain of them except generosity If spread in the earth no meanness would be found in it. They slaughter from the huge camels the fat ones what ... If it were in Iram no craving would have touched it. If people were from them one and they counted: ... Who is the generous? Generosity would point towards him. I did not know is "their Mutlaq" more dewy and generous or His father, or "Faris" or this "their Safouk" But I asked the dew about them and it said: Alas ... All is generous, and the most generous is the last of them. He almost from the generosity of morals gives what is In the earth and he sees that dew is frowning. He gave as a boy so he surpassed the generosity of "Harim" ... And does Harim rival a youth in giving. Ask about his favors his enemies for they ... From counting what they proved of their little were bored. O "Shammari" we saw from his gifts ... What paper nor pen can count. I praised to my hearing about you what fell short ... From matching it in its pouring the rains. I moved in you with my thoughts rhymes that do not ... Cease to be struck as proverbs so they harmonize.

text: And I did not want by my praise in you a prize ... Even if the nations became rich from your flow. But I am a man who loves the generous and who ... Were to the best Vizier in creation servants. Since you emptied capacity in his advice ... And you were his judge when the Persians transgressed. You fought them sincerely in love of a victor ... Were it not "Dawud" I would have said the man is "Mu'tasim". You supported him with cousins lions ... They sold to every danger their souls. So they attacked in the morning Persians who opposed and transgressed ... With sharp swords thought to be meteors above them. They attacked them in the morning but you are their leader Were it not for you they would not have broken heads nor cut. When they attacked them on short-haired pure horses ... If they were not mountains they soared with them. High noses their bits did not soften ... If from others in an accident bits softened. They drew swords against black faces so since They sheathed their flashes the darkness cleared with them. Rawafid who thought the dawn of guidance charcoal And charcoal is not like the shining whiteness. They sought enmity of one whose impulses remained ... With sharp swords from the transgressors taking revenge. And since he made them taste the spear trembling ... And the Mashrafi sword with it the lion-like bold. They returned in disgrace on heels pelting them With white and brown swords the heroes of war the old. And the armored ones but with hearts so how often ... They attacked and did not armor except their hearts. So you were the boldest of them a colt to a dust ... And the white swords scatter and the spears organize. Lions helped you their sayer said: ... Draw the blades and to the rope of Allah hold fast. So the Persians chirped like ostrich chicks and does ... The Persians clash with the Arabs in their attacks? To Allah are Arabs who obeyed the command of a unsheathed ... And a lion who has from his spears a thicket. Were it not for him the blackness would cover the rejection of Persians "Black faces if they are not wronged they wrong". But he drove them away from him with an unsheathed sword So they surrendered the glory when he drew and were defeated. Pride "Safouk" because you supported a victor ... By him the examples in his days were sealed. This and when Safouk supported this advanced Vizier, and the Caliph who by his politics which is not found in his contemporaries becomes great, he granted him "Anah" and what follows it of villages, and this is a giving I have not seen from other than him to the like of Safouk happened. As for the Vizier, he has cases of generosity, judging for him that he is "Ibn Jala and the climber of mountain paths", and when with Safouk he acted, Safouk served him so he became great and majestic, so he opposed his enemies, and allied with his allies, and became to him slave of hands, envied for that in the settled and the Bedouin, and as if the veiled Vizier looked in what he did to the saying of Al-Muhallab: I wondered at who buys slaves with his money, and does not enslave the free with his gift. And as if Safouk only made himself a slave for the saying of who said in this field: Not who bought you is your master, rather your master is who elevated you and gave you authority. I will mention of the Vizier's gifts to Safouk what the tongue of thanks is short of recounting. As for Safouk's generosity, it is what proverbs were struck with, and opposites and likes acknowledged, until one who attended his food mentioned to me, that he surpasses Ibn Sinan and Ibn Mamah. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Safouk is a proverb in generosity among the common people and if they wanted to refute the claim of a claimer of generosity they said: "By Allah Lawk (if only you were) Safouk". Meaning: By Allah you do not reach this description unless you were Safouk and Lawk origin is: Law Annaka (If you were). Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Safouk was killed treacherously by the hand of one of the Turkish governors in the year 1840 or 1841 AD. His father married him to Amsha daughter of the Sheikh of Tayy in the year 1225 AH. He has two other wives who are Salma daughter of his uncle Mutlaq bin Muhammad and Abta daughter of his cousin Bunayyah bin Qurainis bin Muhammad. These two girls quarreled and sought judgment from Ali bin Sarihan, to differentiate between their fathers so he said a poem starting with:

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: O girl the differentiator between the two is a liar Before me the Sheikhs of tribes were unable with it. He praised both their fathers and did not differentiate. This is the text of the complete poem. Ibn Sarihan said: O girl the differentiator between the two is a liar Before me the Sheikhs of tribes were unable with it. If you gather the people they and the companions They would not adjust your right nor was it said leaning. O Hissah whom not every attracter brought ... O daughter of the giver of named thoroughbreds. If the rain of the season decreases and the measure is at the door And the sky clears, the market has no resilience. And if they promoted with the camp ugly spoils And the lean tribes stayed away from them. To the one who has the dabdob and for the neck a butcher Breaker over the food in the banks of Hail. A giver what is in the palm a restrainer what he brought ... Cheerer of the hem of the house fulfilling of qualities. Hinderer of the opponent voider of all causes Resolver carrier of heavy loads. If groups came to him with the ground fog He throws with the edge of the sword whoever came to him attacking. He has an attack in which the marj finds a runner ... With the abundance of the opponent's horses the stabbing of descendants. And if a Bedouin came to him he approached like a bringer ... The morning the choice thoroughbreds are cleared for him. His gift is from the best of his door to students ... Sheikh of Sheikhs and winner of every tall thing. His rumors oh how far they are with the strangers ... The mountain carrier of heavy loads. I copied from Sheikh Mandil's notebooks the saying of Abu Anqa from Abda from Shammar, addressing Safouk Al Jarba and boasting of his people: O Safouk see the red turbans a noise From the group of "Ibn Shuraim" they stood for "Ba'almaykh". I knew their faces when he took refuge ... The abundance of their conversations and they rose Masalikh. O Safouk indeed some issues are foolishness ... What a pity we anger them and please the Tababikh. A group for us we settle with them every need ... See their gain on the day of meeting is Majawikh. Those whose gains on the day of clamor ... Strong horses their nostrils like bellows. Basri Al-Wudaihi said from a poem praising Sheikh Safouk Al Jarba: I climbed a tall cairn that rose with me ... The watchtower of "Arwa" overlooking that from it. I looked at the Khabur seeing Adhib ... Western Tel Nmail a stage split from it. I looked at the house of the Sheikh the illness of the warrior ... Safouk heavy of weight protector of its homeland. A Sheikh and his sight is not from near ... And he does not desist from his will the day he forbids. The house is built and the smoke is like a stream ... The stream of Iraq whose smoke howled. He brings forward dishes in which is mixed and nerve ... And the eaters of food did not decrease from it. Abdullah bin Rabi'ah said about Safouk Al Jarba during his praise of Abdul Muhsin Al-Sa'dun: And he is the one who let Al-Suwaiti enemy of the people ... And the Shammari to the Sham chases his litter. And Safouk from the battle of Al-Muqayyar to today ... Leading the heart of the ostrich his peer. Sheikh Abdullah bin Hadhdhal Sheikh of Anazah addressing Sheikh Safouk - and it is among what I found in Sheikh Mandil's notebooks: "Marjan" bring my mare in her cover ... And milk for her from the milk of the herd of Khawawir. After the fodder drag the rest of the dinner for her ... From a Mansaf the guests did not lessen. I will ride her the ride of the bucket rope to the pulley ... And bring her down the bringing down of a bucket on a well.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: O Safouk I have for the Sayafa a beauty I do not forget it unless I forget the shining stars. I come to you with "Al-Waylan" the choice of his men ... Cutting the groups destroyers of battalions. In the palm a polished sword its ignition increases ... Leaving the fragments of the enemy's heads scattered. Dakhil bin Na'im from the tribes of Al-Sayih said, threatening Safouk Al Jarba: If you come to Abu Farhan say to him: We crossed ... Jazaa'a we do not let the nose be trodden. And if "Al-Arwam" all ride on our trace We must O Safouk shake the head. And we on the war of your ancestors were patient ... It is not from you and coming O wolf of the ropes. Before "Al-Jazira" when "Najd" was our homes ... And our dead in it chase on mares. O Safouk by Allah we do not leave our intoxication Unless "Al-Jazira" is empty there are no people in it. If the belt is a span we measured ... Throwing the armored from old is a base for us. Dr. Shafiq Al-Kamali said: It is narrated about Sheikh Safouk Al-Faris Al Jarba - and he lived at the beginning of the thirteenth century Hijri - one of the Sheikhs of the Shammar tribe - that he was in a council of the councils of Baghdad, so a man entered the council and everyone celebrated him, and he won their respect so he asked about him, and it was said to him that he is Sheikh So-and-so. He said: He is the Sheikh of which tribe? It was said to him: He is not a tribal Sheikh but rather the Sheikh of the Naqshbandi order, which is a religious order. His answer was: Religion has no engravings (nuqush), meaning there are no engravings or decorations in religion. Radhan Abu Anqa said in eulogy of Sheikh Safouk: Since you were absent from us O son of my brother his way Happiness was absent from our dwelling and the laws. And we graze the grazing of game and flee a fleeing And we became like the flock of goats without a billy goat. Farhan bin Safouk Al Jarba. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Perhaps the one who took over the leadership after Safouk was his son Farhan Pasha, and I have seen a mention of him in colloquial poetry in the saying of a poet from Zubaid, singing of the victory of Al Ghubain from Anazah over Farhan Al Jarba: They closed upon you with polished swords No, the prisoner of necessities "Farhan" did not cry. The story of this verse as I read in Sheikh Mandil's notebooks: That a man from Zubaid moved away from Farhan Al Jarba, for a crime he committed, and took refuge with Al Ghubain from Anazah, and stayed with them for a period. Then their lands were hit by drought so they needed to graze in the Jazira, and they asked Al Jarba for a specific period for grazing so he permitted them. When he knew that the Zubaidi was with them he sent someone to take his camels. So the Sheikh of Al Ghubain stood up and said: Whoever does not pass by the tent of the Zubaidi our neighbor and compensate him with a she-camel is not a Ghubaini! So every owner of a herd began taking a mount from it to the Zubaidi's camels, until they returned to him what was taken from him and an increase of fifteen mounts. Then a man from Al Ghubain came late, so they said to him: The Zubaidi is sufficed and got more than his right. He said: I am not failing my group, if you do not take it to him I will slaughter it! When they returned to their country, a group from Shammar of the Jazira raided them, so Al Ghubain defeated the Shamamrah. When their neighbor the Zubaidi who returned to Al Jarba in the Jazira after his crime ended knew, he said: O cloud Ghurra originated from a cloud ... From "Al-Jazira" went west towards "Hawran". Raining on "Al-Ghibnan" they drive its torrent The people of the quarters who are on horses knights. They rode upon them forcing the calamity ... They loosened the shutters of the reins and halters. They closed upon them with polished swords ... No, the prisoner of necessities Farhan did not cry. Faris and Abdul Karim Al Jarba. I do not know who took over after Farhan except that there are two who took over consecutively after Farhan, and they are from the grandsons of Faris bin Muhammad without doubt: One of them: Faris Al Jarba whom Lady Anne Blunt mentioned in her journey that he was the Sheikh of the Jazira in the era of Muhammad Al-Abdullah Al-Rashid.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: The second: Abdul Karim Al Jarba and his brother Mutlaq, and I do not know which of them was the Sheikh, except that they were contemporaries of Talal bin Abdullah Al-Rashid, and Abdullah Al-Faisal, so they are older than the contemporary of Muhammad Al-Abdullah Al-Rashid. Abdul Karim has great fame among the people of Najd, and I did not find this fame for him among the historians of Iraq. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: It is likely that Abdul Karim and Mutlaq are sons of Farhan bin Safouk, and that Abdul Karim took over directly after Farhan then after him Faris. Safouk is a contemporary of Abdullah Al-Rashid, and has a relationship in helping him during his ordeal with Al Ali, and perhaps there was intermarriage between them. Sheikh Mandil dictated to me these two verses by Abdullah bin Ali Ibn Rashid addressing his brother Ubaid after they returned from Iraq and married their sister to Al Jarba. Abdullah said: O Ubaid nothing remains for us but a need And it is a need that is neither bought nor sold. And O Ubaid indeed some meanings are foolishness ... By Allah if he intends lost lost. Among the news of Abdul Karim Al Jarba is this story attributed by Sheikh Ibn Khamis to one of the Sheikhs of Al Jarba. Ibn Khamis said about Abdul Aziz bin Eid "Al-Izzi" the shepherd of Al-Barra: That he said these verses praising one of the Sheikhs from Al Jarba. O Al-Zir O Al-Zahhar O Al-Nimr O Al-Dhib O Al-Layth O Al-Layuth O the Cub O Al-Dabb. Confronter of the battalion of soldiers if feared With the sword for the necks of the bold ones a butcher. His fault if people said there is a fault in him For the ghee over the flattened tray of camels pouring. Ibn Khamis said: It is said that when he went deep in bringing these strong words in this strong poetic style, and Al Jarba was girdled with a golden belt with a precious dagger, the praised one felt vanity and admiration, and swelled until this belt could not bear him, so it snapped, and it was the first of the poet's gifts! Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Ibn Khamis was followed in this attribution by quoting him both Al-Huqail and the author of "Al-Azhar" and Al-Kamali. The correct is what Sheikh Mandil published, and Ibrahim told me that the verses are by Khudair Al-Su'aylik from a poem praising Abdul Karim Al Jarba starting with: O Sheikh I came to you on the grey camels Coming from the house of the lovers crawling. Mandil said: It was said: That when he heard it he gave him a prize of fifteen camels with their load of provisions. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Here is the text of the complete poem as narrated by Sheikh Mandil. Khudair Al-Su'aylik said: O Sheikh I came to you on the grey camels Coming from the house of the lovers crawling. It crawled on me and crawled from me with approximation ... The livestock decreased O shelter of everyone who feared. From our house we came to your house strangers ... Heading for a star that neither changed nor disappeared. Choosing you O source of generosity and goodness ... May Allah not disappoint for the generous a seeker. Peace from a loving heart without doubt ... To him the young repent and the one who aged becomes young. O the jewel the Nariz O the perfumed with goodness O the slender O the neighing O the horse of requests. O Al-Zir O Al-Zahhar O Al-Nimr O Al-Dhib O Al-Layth O Al-Layuth O the Cub O Al-Dabb. O the fierce the lion severe of strikes O the queen O the breaker of his opponent and strangers. O the rare the eagle the punishment of watchtowers O surpasser of his generation far and near. Confronter of the battalion of soldiers if feared Cover of the virgins if the fog covered the camels. Your fault if the smoke rose as if it were the stream With the sword for the necks of the bold ones a butcher. And your fault if people said there is a fault in you For the ghee over the flattened tray of camels pouring. And slaughtering sheep and large camels rough of hocks And giving fillies, and spending money without count.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: And in you is a sign pouring the single bent ones And giving food and for the extra gains a gainer. And a leopardess you drag to the enemies and foreigners ... You surprise with it the heedless of your opponent with causes. And after this by the help there are no defects in you Sweeter than sugar on the liver of a drinker. We came to you on camels grey of bags To see you O show clear of fangs. The free falcon strikes with deadly palms And the follower his hunter from the game did not bring. And you are the one who fulfills all duties As if you are "Hudaib Al-Sham" with the load blaming. You bend to Abu "Salfiq" there are no lies in it ... Sheikh of generosity giver of long necks. How often you gave those who come to you seekers How many came to you from time afflicted. And you relieved his worry with great gifts From a spring rising as "Al-Zab" rises. Allah honored that you are good and do good And good is gathered from you O pure of lineage. And it is not much O calmer of difficulties ... Your deeds are counted by the one in the loins. Prince Al-Sudairi mentioned that Abdul Karim is nicknamed among Shammar and Anazah as the Drunkard of the Madmen, and he cited a poem by Hada Al-Hamdani, praising Abdul Karim with it, while seeking neighborhood with him and Abdul Karim granted him neighborhood and he sat with him. From this poem is his saying: Name and obey me on the camels and we move ... To Abdul Karim who is remembered for his deeds. To the Sheikh confronter of the faces coming ... And whoever the dust of nights closed on him came to him. I found in Rosel's book about Al-Ruwalah from what my translator Professor Nasser Al-Ulaywi provided me this war song (Ahydiyah) by one of the poets threatening Abdul Karim Al Jarba: For the eyes of blondes that hovered ... We hear in them the ringing of the bell. Either you threw to Abdul Karim ... Riding the horse is forbidden to me. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: Muhammad bin Yahyan, may Allah have mercy on him, told me around the year 1376 AH - about a rivalry that took place between Abdul Karim Al Jarba and his brother Mutlaq, so people feared differentiating between them, and so did their mother except that she mentioned that Mutlaq while breastfeeding holds the nipple and does not pay attention to his mother's cooing to him, while Abdul Karim releases the breast and plays with his mother's cheerfulness and laughs to her, so people understood from that that she distinguished Abdul Karim with generosity. Due to the excessive generosity of Abdul Karim they nickname him "Abu Khawdhah" (Father of Take) as will be explained in Fajhan Al-Farawi's poem. I copied from Sheikh Mandil's notebook these verses by the poet Radhan Ibn Anqa Al-Shammari, praising Abdul Karim Al Jarba, when he clothed him with his fur coat while not knowing him, because he found him a stranger in a winter night. Radhan said: Yesterday was not like yesterdays ... From a blower blowing behind the house and roaring. The pregnant camels and fat ones become in it ... As if you cut their backs with saws. The weak camels become crouching ... The noses of the crooked weak ones began to pour. Were it not for "Abu Mudbagh" this would be my death ... In a night where no guards meet me. A gift not from the clear ones ... "A fur coat" and as if he drove to me white camels. His father is like him giving the named ones ... Strong hoofed long nails. Sheikh Mandil mentioned that Abdul Karim's maternal uncle is Ibn Sabila from Al Shuraym from Abda. So Ibn Sabila's daughters are four: Mother of Sheikh Abdul Karim, and mother of Al-Ajl from the Sheikhs of Abda, his grandfather Iqab bin Ajl, maternal uncle of Abdul Aziz Ibn Mutaib Al Rashid, and mother of Al-Rim Sheikhs of Abda, and mother of Al Fuhaid people of Al-Asyah known as Mutayrah. Radhan Abu Anqa said addressing Sheikh Abdul Karim: O riders of the swaying straps ... Red and they are from below clothed like raw cloth.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: Stretched after they were unbroken ... They grazed the bones of the quarter year after year. They show speech from my brain anecdotes ... From the head of an old man afflicted by deceit and passion. They arrive at Abdul Karim "Abu Nayef" ... May his glory last throughout the days. O Sheikh O you who are for the belt successors O like the sprout of Pleiades when it rose. O spring of rulers fulfilling of costs Were it not for the breach in you from the breach. You inclined your head towards the owner of fines ... Not sitting is your glory with his head nor standing. Holder of grudge in the clean hearts ... Hasty in carrying the pincers blame. The camels went west from you today afraid What is the matter with you O distracter of every rain cloud? Three groups needing descriptions ... Heading for the house of "Jad'an" and "Wadham". Maybe you see them regrets do not benefit ... Something passes today count it from the year. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: This poem is from what I copied from Sheikh Mandil's notebooks, and he mentioned about its occasion that Al-Ahdab and his people from Al-Thabit from Shammar, killed an adversary of theirs named Ibn Dar'an, in Abdul Karim Al Jarba's house, so Abdul Karim got angry and ordered them to leave him. However, the poet Radhan feared that Al-Ahdab and his people would resort to the enemies, and could not advise Abdul Karim immediately, so Abdul Karim's wife tricked for the poet by ripping the shelter of the tent from every side, while Abdul Karim was sleeping, when he woke up he ordered covering the tent and fixing it so she said: I uncovered the tent for the sake of the enemies. When she paved the occasion for him he presented his advice in the aforementioned poem. I found in Sheikh Mandil's notebooks these verses by Sheikh Abdul Karim Al Jarba on the occasion of the "Bey" the state commissioner requesting his Kuhaylah mare and his insistence that he would take it with a price or without a price. Abdul Karim said: You sent to me O "Bey" a letter that scares ... You request the torment of the twisting branches. I want when the groups dyed ... I defend on it with the groups of Al-Tanaya. O "Bey" it is not a lark in the plates ... This is "Kuhaylah" like the goat of the Bedouin. I want when my group come shouting ... In an hour the birds of death hovered. The sale by Allah we do not sell "Al-Kuhaylah" ... Nay nor do we give it generously for a quarter of a night. I refuse when they ascended with a long one ... I defend on it at the end of the rejected ones. The "Bey" did not concern me nor did "Sharif" concern ... We are removers of the enemy and the bordering. By force we do not give the weight of a loaf ... And at satisfaction we are big in gifts.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: Fahd Al-Marik, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Professor Adham Al-Jundi says: I was one day in the club of the late Mashal Pasha Al Jarba, in Damascus, so Sheikh Mashal was asked about the greatest thing he heard and saw of the rare stances of the brave, so he answered saying: The most wonderful and important scene he saw in his life is the bravery of a knight from the knights of the Anazah tribe.. Sheikh Mashal continues in his talk according to the narrator's account until he said: We were raiders from our tribe "i.e. Shammar tribe" led by the late Abdul Karim Al Jarba, intending to raid the Anazah tribe, so we found camels herded by a girl, so we seized them, believing that they were an easy bite, and the look of the girl specialized in herding camels drew our attention, for she was looking at us with a look of mockery, or recklessness, and we did not think that behind her look was what was behind it of a buried secret. We had not covered a not far distance until a knight caught up with us alone and when he approached us he asked us for "Al-Hadhiyah" i.e. the gift as is the custom followed in such a case, for the seizing one according to the followed custom must give from his booty. Mashal says: We did not hesitate to give him two she-camels, thinking that was enough for him, but he returned and asked for "Al-Hadhiyah" a second time so we gave him two she-camels as well, then he returned a third time and asked, so we gave him a similar number, then he returned a fourth time asking for "Al-Hadhiyah" but in a tone suggesting that he was not begging, as it seemed to us from the first glance in his previous request, but rather this time he was challenging, and therefore six of our knights came out to fight him while we drove the camels we seized, so he remained for a while wrestling with the knights between attack and retreat, and after that our companions' mares caught up with us empty of their saddles from their knights whom this knight exterminated. So we had no choice but to bring out knights more in number than the previous ones while the rest of us continued driving the camels, and as soon as we took a period, the mares of our people caught up with us whose fate was like the fate of their predecessors. The result was that the knight terrified us and cast fear into the heart of each of us, so we fled leaving him his camels, seizing safety after he killed youths from the best of our knights. After, I found Mr. Al-Jundi the narrator of the story amazed at the heroism performed by the knight, and although it is truly a supernatural heroism, but he is amazed and admiring at the same time at the late Mashal Al Jarba's admission of his enemy's bravery. But I personally did not find that strange by virtue of my firm knowledge of Arab morals. News of Abdul Karim and Farhan will come at the end of this chapter. Abdul Karim died hanged, hanged by the Turks around the year 1265 AH. Among those who cared to praise Abdul Karim is Fajhan Al-Farawi, so from that is his M-rhymed poem. Muhammad bin Yahyan, may Allah have mercy on him, told me it and I do not record the text of his wording and Rudayman bin Husain Al-Shammari dictated it to me, and Ibn Bulaihid published two verses from it, and Sheikh Mandil cited it in his book he said it when he went to Abdul Karim Al Jarba, after his hesitation between Abu Bandar Talal bin Abdullah bin Rashid and the son of Imam Abdullah Al-Faisal: Fajhan Al-Farawi said: I took for myself between the two a pause ... Between "Abu Bandar" and "Son of the Imam". After them we take on the camels a rush ... To the lands of the smiling faces the noble. To witness "Al Jarban" is a duty and pilgrimage ... From among the builders of hair and tents. As for generosity a clamor and noise ... No one rivals them south and north. My destination is my arrival place when I head ... Abdul Karim the lion the goal of my aim. How many a one came from far marching ... Wants to see you O far of mark. And how many a time he left on the opponent a dust ... With leopards dragging it like the middle of darkness. You find in the heart of who opposes him a shake ... From fear of him sleep is forbidden to him. And spears widening in the backs gaps ... And the sharp backs that cut bones. On fillies terrorizing the heart their dust ... Knights drudging the enemy in the crowd.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: My last speech to "Abu Khawdhah" directed ... The bank of the Euphrates if thirst drives you. O Allah O Governor of Destinies save him ... Since he is generous and from inheritances of nobles. Then his poem which Rudayman bin Husain dictated to me and mentioned that Al-Farawi said it after his return from Al Jarba and Sheikh Mandil published it in his book. Fajhan said referring to Abdul Karim Al Jarba giving him a mare: My stories with the brave ones are novel ... Not nonsense returning to nothing. My heart loves the fluttering of the strap ... Sleep of the open to me is strikes and bed. I brought the horse and brought "Hadba" lush Solid hooves from the mounts of "Al-Abwash". I am not facing it like the color of a carcass ... If a raider goes I went a traveler. Sheikh Al-Asi Among the prominent notables of Al Jarba is Abu Al-Hadi Sheikh Al-Asi from Al-Jaz'ah and he is the Sheikh of all Shammar in the Jazira. I found in handwritten notebooks of Sheikh Prince Ahmad bin Muhammad Al-Sudairi in which he collected war songs of horses news related to Al-Asi, and his son Al-Hadi, so I copied them here. Prince Al-Sudairi had entrusted me with explaining his book so I finished the first part, and when he died, may Allah have mercy on him, his son Mish'al retrieved the originals of the book from me, with what was explained of it, and I do not know what happened to those precious volumes. Among their news is what relates to the dispute between them and Al-Thabit, and Prince Al-Sudairi, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified the cause of hostility between Al-Hadi and Al-Thabit, mentioning that Al-Arjani Al-Arifi Al-Zafiri was a neighbor to Munawir bin Suqi Sheikh of Al-Afarit from Abda of Shammar, then he left them and returned after seven years, but before reaching Munawir, Al-Hadi raided him and looted two herds from him. Munawir apologized for not aiding Al-Arjani, because he was his neighbor seven years ago, but Al-Arjani insisted on his help and aroused his chivalry, and argued that Al-Hadi took him while he was on his way to neighborhood, so chivalry aroused in Munawir's head, and he went to seek help from Mut'ib Al-Hadab, and his group Al-Thabit. Mut'ib rode to his aid with sixty horsemen and descended on Al-Hadi interceding for Al-Arjani's two herds, but Al-Hadi refused his mediation. Al-Hadab rode his steed angry, so Al-Hadi called him mocking: In front of you are the red ones "meaning his she-camels"! With this sentence he challenges them to take his she-camels. So Al-Hadab and his group lined up in two rows singing this war song by a poet from Al-Thabit: We are the people of the mutilated and sure ... If they turned back and came with us. We are your shelter from the north ... And all the warring are beside us. O who asks our Sheikh ... O our group what is our sin. And they passed by Al-Hadi's red camels, and seized them. So Al-Hadi asked for his steed, and called his group, so his father Al-Asi hastened to order tying his son Al-Hadi, and putting iron in his hands and feet, as he ordered returning Al-Arjani's two herds to Al-Hadab, with a group from Al-Kharsa and in return Al-Hadab returned Al-Hadi's camels. As for Al-Hadi, he fainted from anger. From this incident the fire of enmity ignited between the two parties, and during the battles between them Al-Hadi was killed, killed by Fahd bin Shukhayr Al-Wudaihi grandson of the poet Basri Al-Wudaihi, and Fahd fled from the island of Iraq and took refuge with Ibn Muhaid in Syria, and remained with him until he died. For this reason Al-Asi expelled his cousins Al-Thabit and Al-Fadaghah, from the island of Iraq, so these two tribes took refuge with Dana Majid from Al-Fid'an, and formed a force for themselves, then they traveled as guests to Al-Asi, and reconciled except that Al-Asi excluded Al-Wadhhan from them, the direct killers of Al-Hadi, and they are still evacuees with Al-Fid'an until now. Perhaps before this circumstance Fahd bin Shukhayr said his poem addressing Al Jarba. Fahd said - as in Prince Al-Sudairi's notebooks -: They said: Visit I said I am not visiting ... The visit of the thick-handed suffices me. Except if the Sheikh says visit and visit And gives me what is like the neck of the gazelle. If I do not kill Daham or the Prince ... Prohibited to me are the wearers of iron.

O its rider convey my greeting to Shukhayr ... Who started with the Sheikh a new rhyme. Your father before you did not kill every good one ... Except the poems nothing praiseworthy was mentioned in him. We ride on the like of the flying pigeons Treading iron and the dress of their people is iron. How many a good one fell in their throats ... Upon him the black beasts of prey feast. Daham Sheikh of the people is not small ... His difference over you O Al-Wudaihi is far. I found in Prince Al-Sudairi's notebooks, may Allah have mercy on him, this war song by a chanter from Al-Thabit from Shammar confirming the killing of Al-Hadi Al Jarba: O who looks for the judgment ... Ask and we are his guess. The lion of the wild stood over him ... And the lion eats his kidney. Al-Asi said several war songs eulogizing his son Al-Hadi, from that is his saying: Mercied O dead of ours ... Mentioned to us under the soil O Al-Hadi. I wish you rise ... And see after you what happened. Munawir asks for milk ... Wants from the red ones ten. He said addressing Al-Hadab Sheikh of Al-Thabit after they killed his son Al-Hadi: O groan I groaned it ... From my conscience O Abu Ali. O curse the father of ... Al-Hadab ... Were it not for the bad one he would blame me. Al-Hadi said eulogizing his son Al-Hadi: O Al-Hadi I do not forget your tear ... Unless the camel forgets the roaring. After losing your squadron ... The world after you turns. How many fell from your spear ... A head with the squadron big. Abdul Jabbar Al-Rawi mentioned that Al-Hadi took over the Sheikhdom of Al Jarban after his father aged so his cousin Jarallah's children competed with him, so Al-Asi said encouraging his son Al-Hadi: For you is a home a meadow of bliss ... Mut'ib and Al-Sayb want it. The Sheikh like you does not sleep ... Tires on cooling it. Al-Hadi said addressing his father: I know it before you say ... A girl arranging her feast. A breaker with the black iron ... In the jaws of who wants it. He said addressing his son Al-Hadi: O Al-Hadi your Lord deluded you ... They went on the pulse of the dust. The son of Al-Zafiri ignored them ... A free falcon took charge of chickens. Al-Asi said: O Al-Hadi this is my guess ... Not the guess of a stepping boy. See your group are the youth of Yemen ... They are not a gathering from a country. O Al-Hadi O bird of the attack ... Whoever came in your face is happy. He said about his eldest son: O offspring I lost it ... Except the brother of Shahah corruption. In it Al-Zu'aili and Al-Dawish ... And Udayb his mother's uncle sure. He said about his son Hadi from the Mas-hub melody: O bird O whose den is in the tall one ... In Al-Mistawi between Abanat and Sawaj. Does not kill except every big mottled one Bird of happiness always on the game disturbing. Al-Asi said urging his grandson Daham: I left all my children ... And called you O son of my son. A den of free ones from free ones ... Preserved and your root is not bad. I left for Abda twice ... And the third for Ibn Jadi. Beware, pay attention do not sleep ... Be aware of your right lest it be lost. Al-Asi said addressing his grandson Daham bin Al-Hadi:

text: O Daham Abda went west ... Sit gird yourself do not sleep. They counted with the arranger of his forelock ... Al-Hadi leader of the herds. Aqil Al-Yawar before assuming the Sheikhdom, used to raid frequently and success accompanied him, so he distributed spoils to the houses of Shammar, so Al-Asi feared the transfer of leadership to him and its snatching from his son, so he said urging his son Hakim to take the leadership and it is from the Huda melody: Whoever wants to drink milk ... Let him descend on Al-Yawar Aqil. Every day he takes for himself Arabs ... Signaling to Shammar with the hem. Struggler O stepping boy ... Gathering money of the noise. Prince Al-Sudairi, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned that the tribes of Al-Thabit and Al-Fadaghah from Sinjara sought help from the Pasha for a while, so they raided Al-Asi, and took his camels Hubub so Al-Asi said: Hubub is mentioned with them ... A milk camel for people of a spear. We must take its revenge ... In a day terrifying the nursing mothers. Its return is obligatory upon us ... An obligation like the obligation of prayer. Al-Asi said on this occasion: Hubub wants a summer resort for it ... Move away from its atmosphere. Move away O people of the spear ... And the war we light its fire. A chanter from Sinjara said replying to Al-Asi: O Al-Asi O big head ... You want the brave deeds just now. Hubub wants for it a morning ... Walking and glaring at its calf. Prince Al-Sudairi, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned that Mut'ib Al-Hadab Sheikh of Al-Thabit took refuge with Ibrahim Pasha. Ibrahim Pasha is originally from Al-Ruwalah, and lived in Iraq, and a group of Arabs gathered around him so he made truce with the Turks and they granted him the title "Pasha". Al-Asi said on this occasion: O messenger towards Al-Hadab ... From behind a planet he turns. After the dwelling of joy ... He descends on Khansa short. O pity O lion of the side ... Sits with no consultant. Al-Asi said replying to Khaz'al one of the slaves of Shammar: O slave we are not upon you ... Upon Jarallah and a father. And your soldiers I subdued them with the sword ... Today and days after. Al-Asi said: Your grandfather to his ancestors is an opponent ... Pot-like, does not tolerate distress. A cloak did not cover you in Barqa ... Your rise is far in Al-Hamad. In you Al-Zu'aili and Al-Dawish ... And Udayb your mother's uncle sure. Al-Sudairi said: A disagreement occurred between Al-Asi and Mutni Al-Sadid Sheikh of Al-Sayih, so Al Jarallah from Al Jarba joined Al-Sadid, and Ibn Hassan Sheikh of Al-Aslam joined Al-Asi although he is counted from Al-Sadid. Al-Asi said on this occasion: The son of the belted Jad'an accompanied him ... Every day he slaps Arabs for him. The war erupted and brave ones were killed in it ... And today the brother of Shahah fought. Prince Al-Sudairi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Al-Thabit were at Al-Asi's for food and he had reconciled with them after they killed his son Al-Hadi, and Al-Asi wanted to frighten them without breaking the covenant of his guests, so Al-Asi put this war song on the tongue of some of his companions, and ordered him to recite it after food in a loud voice: O Al-Asi cut their heads ... For the eyes of the one who rode the litter. Al-Hadi is left in Al-Mahas ... And the eyelid did not blink happy. Al-Asi said addressing Ubaid bin Shuraib: O Ubaid where are the first ones ... Those whose consultation is strong? Those who close the ambush ... And their stabs in their chests. If you obeyed my advice O living ones ... We put you in their graves. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: In another place of Prince Al-Sudairi's notebooks he attributed this war song to a chanter from Anazah with this formula:

text: O Zaid where are the first ones ... Those whose consultation is strong? Confronters of the face of the ambush ... And their stabs in their chests. Ubaid bin Shuraib Al-Shammari was sharp-tongued, inciting tribes to take revenge, and he asked for Aqil Al-Yawar's neighborhood, so Aqil stipulated that he stop stirring up sedition, on condition that he gives him any salary he wants. Ubaid said addressing Aqil: Aqil my speech is silver and gold ... I do not say speech that is weak. The rule as long as it is for Banu Uthman ... The rule belongs to the Creator it stops. And the rule before you Sultan removed it ... He went stripped having no follower. And the brothers of Noura left Barzan ... And the House Al-Sharif left it. In another place of Al-Sudairi's notebooks the narration appeared like this: Aqil my speech is silver and coral ... And we did not speak the speech of the weak. And the sisters of Noura left Barzan ... ......................etc. Once - as Prince Al-Sudairi mentioned - Al Jarban were preparing to raid Barhah Pasha, and this Barhah is from Al-Kawakibah from Al-Ruwalah who settled in Iraq, and led a number of tribes, and the state gave him the title of Pasha to secure his side, and benefit from his influence in subjugating the Bedouins. When Ubaid bin Shuraib felt the march of Al Jarban he asked them to permit him to go to his family at Barhah's, and his intention was to warn Barhah because he is a friend of his, so they permitted him after taking covenants and charters from him to conceal the news, and it was hard for Ubaid to break his covenant so he said this war song riddling: Allah from a snake that crept ... Between my dress and my shout. I read a Maghribi reading ... And no one understood my reading. My affliction did not come from far ... My affliction is in my group. I cannot reveal its secret ... The wall of my building would collapse. Despite repeating this war song, Barhah's group did not understand it until after Al Jarban defeated them a severe defeat. Prince Muhammad Al-Sudairi, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated that the government of Turkey in Iraq sent a squadron searching for Al-Asi, so he took refuge with his brother, and hid in a lote tree next to the house, and asked his brother to delude them that he is the Prince until Al-Asi fled. When the matter was revealed the squadron returned without avail, so Ubaid bin Shuraib said mocking Al-Asi: The forwarding of Al-Asi to his brother ... A strong bottle for his cat. It attacked a grammar he bought ... Fat and flour it touched. It climbed on the fat bag ... Passed it and touched it. What a pity O Sheikh of the herds ... "A chapter" from his house forgot him. He took refuge on the lote tree behind him ... The thorn of the long one pierced him. Al-Asi said: Justice tore his dress a tunic ... And tears filled her eyes. We wait for Dana Subhi to come ... And honor they do not throw it. Al-Asi said: I do not want the war of the leaning one ... A young boy and his weapon is a spear. We wait for Dana Subhi to come ... People of the vague armors. Al-Asi said: O nose say to the aggressor ... Wounds if you forgot. He waits and we take our revenge ... The morning is not like the night. From above honored horses ... From above them I sold and bought. Al-Asi said: From the turn of Salem and the Sharif ... We are not soft to the harsh. We are like the cheat of Iraq ... We catch up over the length of time. Al-Asi said: The banner is the banner of Al-Darat ... And today our banner reached. The strength is the strength of Abu Aqil ... And my strength from the knee reached. Last year my drink was milk ... And today my food is onions.

text: After my riding the thoroughbred ... Today my mount is lean. Al-Asi said: What a pity my bird was lost ... I lost in the days of release. At Al-Khulaibis his guess ... Or the people of Al-Jad'a sure. Al-Asi said: O messenger towards Al-Fid'an ... Its decreed is not prevented. And horses of Al-Sayafa that you say ... Oh how often you resorted to their chests. From the turn of Salem and the Sharif ... The horses we are their light. Al-Asi said praising Muslat bin Mulhim Sheikh of Al-Jubur, because he helped him in his wars with Al-Thabit: Abu Shibl led the wars ... He did not circulate the goods from us. The Sheikh is the glory of relatives Were it not for him by Allah we would not have lived. Al-Asi said: You became for Ibn Haima? Lean ... Be driven away may you go to destruction. There is no boy who pays attention to him ... He fills him in the aorta with an injury. Al-Asi said: The blond of little tail tortured you ... And seduced you the undoer of the curl. The daughter of the bad one do not take her ... She brings you a son like his father. Al-Hadi said: From the turn of Salem and the Sharif ... O Mut'ib and you are our right. The Sayhi brought his affliction ... From the Jazira he repelled us. Prince Al-Sudairi cited this war song in another place of his notebooks attributed to Al-Asi with this wording: O Mut'ib and you are our glory. Al-Rawi said: This is the tribe of Shammar Al-Jarabah in Iraq, the banner of Sheikhdom in it was tied to Al-Hadi while his father Al-Asi was alive, and to Aqil Al-Yawar while his father Abdul Aziz was alive. Abu Abd al-Rahman said: He is Aqil bin Abdul Aziz bin Farhan Ibn Safouk bin Faris bin Muhammad bin Salim Al Jarba. He died in the year 1940 AD and the leadership is still in his offspring on November 14. Among the news of Al Jarban whose time I do not verify is an incident recorded by one of the poets of Shammar in the Jazira Ali bin Sarihan reported by Fahd Al-Marik, may Allah have mercy on him, and mentioned that it is in eulogy of Zahir Al Jarba whom his cousin Fahd Al Jarba killed: By Allah upon you by your face O she-camel ... Do not cut the hearts of people ringing. You lost a young camel like Buji ... Who if he entered the sale for twenty. And I lost Zahir wide of tracks ... Who in his house the poor are satisfied. Khuraisat? Above the horses like towers ... On the ambush and the dear life loosening. Al-Marik mentioned that the representatives of the Shammar Al-Furat tribe are from the Al Jarban family in both the Syrian and Iraqi parliaments when there is an election in the two countries. Al-Marik mentioned what relates to Zaid bin Amr Al Jarba who migrated with some of his group from the Euphrates to the Turkish lands adjacent to the Syrian borders in the year 1350 AH. About one of the battles of Shammar and Anazah, Muwaidi Al-Baraziyah said boasting of the bravery of her people Al-Mutran: And they stopped with Al Jarban like the dust ... And the Sheikh was hit by a hammer that split his jaws. Influence of Al Jarba in Iraq. About the influence of Al Jarba in Iraq, Kahhalah said quoting Jones: Jarbat Shammar is one of the tribes of Iraq whose influence extended to the northern land between the two rivers from north of Sinjara and the Khabur river to Saqlawiya west of Baghdad and sometimes to Al-Hayy. James Felix Jones described this tribe in the year 1853 AD saying: They represent terror for the Turkish authorities and for the residents, and they live in the wilderness and wastelands, and in areas that seem uninhabited, and the authorities do not wish to acquire them, as they launch from them in raiding acts looting everything their hands reach, until they reach the gates of the city in Baghdad. When the Turkish authorities failed to repel them, they finally agreed to pay their leader a monthly salary to ensure his loyalty, and despite that agreement, small looting and robbery occurred sometimes. Abdul Jabbar Al-Rawi said:
