text: The Ottoman government, over the extent of its authority and the area of the country it managed, did not have any significant control over the desert. Throughout this rule, for example, you would see the Shammar tribes moving in the Jazira between Khabur, Tigris, and Euphrates. All the authorities did at that time was to appoint two Sheikhs, one "Badawah" (Bedouin) who travels with his tribe and moves with them, and the other "Madinah" (City) whose center is between Baghdad and Mosul, thus being close to the authorities to help them with Bedouin administration. The first is elected from the brave, generous Sheikhs successful in raiding, while the other is from those of prestige and gentle disposition. But the condition in both is that both Sheikhs must be from Al Muhammad because they are the house of Sheikhdom, and the house of Sheikhdom is restricted to Al Muhammad, and this is what we detailed in the second part of this book. The reason for this is that most people of Mosul and Baghdad know Al Muhammad, Sheikhs of Shammar Al Jarba, and they are the children of Farhan Pasha. The Ottoman government often got angry at them, or threatened them. It happened once, as I noted in another chapter, that one of the governors got angry at one of the Sheikhs and wrote him a threatening letter, concluding it with the saying of Ibn Al-Wardi: Avoid the Sultan and beware his tyranny ... Do not quarrel with one who if he says he does. So the Sheikh answered him seeking his sympathy, repeating in the conclusion of his letter to him his saying: Avoid the Sultan and beware his tyranny ... Do not quarrel with one who if he packs up he leaves. The Ottoman rule did not limit itself to taking the path of Sheikhdom as a means of control, but it established fortresses for soldiers to be a center of power to impose influence from which large forces march from time to time. This is what happened on the day a large campaign marched from those places against Shammar when its Sheikh Abdul Karim Al Jarba spread corruption in the Mosul region, so it arrested him and hanged him at the head of the Mosul bridge. The aggression of Shammar and its Sheikh on Mosul was known at that time as "Kharab Abdul Karim" (Ruin of Abdul Karim), and that goes back to about one hundred and thirty years ago. We must mention in this regard that Mosul suffered ruin at the hands of two, one of them Abdul Karim Al Jarba in the past, and the second Abdul Karim Qasim recently, and they are of one name with different surnames. Despite the means followed by the Ottoman rule, the Shammar tribes continued to raid the Anazah tribes, especially in Al-Shamiya, causing chaos and aggression against villages and roads passed by the raid, and the crossings crossed from on the Euphrates river. I still remember the days of childhood in Rawa those many raids and how the long spears filled its valley, as the Bedouins used the crossings and fords in Rawa and its neighborhood as a theater for them. I still remember the names of the brave men who were mentioned who used to lead the raid and the competition between them, especially from the Sheikhdom family like Munif, Nayef, and Nawwaf sons of Jarallah and Al-Hadi bin Al-Asi, who were competing for the Sheikhdom in the Jazira, until the matter reached the point of fighting and assassinating each other. Fathers at that time used to encourage their children to take over the Sheikhdom and urge them to it. Al-Asi used to repeat to his son Al-Hadi: The Sheikh like you does not sleep ... Strives to cool it. Just as he used to praise him over his brothers by saying: "O offspring after Abu Shahah corruption". The situation continued between the Bedouin tribes raiding each other, and they fulfill by that their pride in their customs which Islam came 1390 years ago and fought and denounced and considered pre-Islamic tribalism, but that did not have any effect on the Bedouins. It is narrated that Farhan Pasha passed one day by a village called "Al-Mushahada" and saw its men with filled bodies and huge statures, so he asked them: Do you raid? They said to him: No, for we cannot raid, and we did not take raiding as a craft. He said to them: Raid those who are weaker (atqa') than you. He said: As for the north in the Mosul region, a banner was formed for the Sheikh of Shammar Daham Al-Hadi, but this banner was not destined for success. After the establishment of the civil rule, the government formed a banner in the north for the Sheikh of Shammar Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar, who was newly elected. He did not accept that his banner be under the command of a British officer, so the government chose the author of this book as a commander for this banner in 20/2/1922.

book_title: Al Jarba Family in History and Literature
text: He said: As for the Jazira ruled by the Shammar tribes, they relied on Sheikh Daham Al Jarba, head of the Shammar tribes in the north in the Jazira and near Mosul. Through him and the Sheikh of Anazah, British armored vehicles began patrolling the Jazira and Al-Shamiya at all times in complete safety, until the movement of these armored vehicles became a mark in the land they traverse. The Bedouins and everyone crossing the desert see the tracks of the armored vehicles clearly, especially in the spring days when the land turns green, except for the tracks of their wheels which do not turn green, so it appears to the viewer like a railway. They appointed for each banner of these banners composed of two hundred camel riders a British commander, assisted by officers from tribal chiefs as is in the Dulaim banner. The banner formed in the Jazira under Sheikh Daham failed in its mission and was cancelled before the establishment of the Iraqi government. When Prince Faisal presided, he turned to appointing Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar, cousin of Sheikh Daham, as Sheikh of the Sheikhs of Shammar, and forming a banner for him, due to his good reputation among the tribes and among the nationalists because he was helpful to the revolutionaries. He ordered one of the officers of the Iraqi revolution in Hijaz and Syria, Mr. Tahsin Ali, to accompany Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar to Baghdad. So he went to him in the Shammar encampments and accompanied him to Baghdad. After deliberations and memoranda, the Iraqi government decided to appoint him Sheikh of the Sheikhs of Shammar. I learned that those deliberations and consultations were taking place between the Court and the British High Commissioner's office, as the Court wanted Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar to be the Sheikh, and the High Commissioner's office wanted Daham, grandson of Al-Asi, to be Sheikh considering that the Sheikhdom was and still is in the house of Al-Asi. Against this view, King Faisal held to his opinion considering that Sheikh Al-Asi was staying in the Ramilan location inside Turkish territory, and that he does not mind giving the Sheikhdom to Al-Asi's grandson if his grandfather Al-Asi leaves his home and descends into Iraqi territory. When this was requested from Daham and he failed to persuade his grandfather to descend into Iraqi territory, the High Commissioner was forced to agree with King Faisal on appointing Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar as Sheikh of the Sheikhs of Shammar and forming a banner for him of two hundred camel riders. It was also decided to appoint Captain Lauder, the British, as commander of this banner which was known as the Northern Camel Corps. I learned finally that Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar, when he knew of the appointment of Captain Lauder for this banner, requested the Court and the Ministry of Interior not to form this force, because he does not agree that there be among the Shammar tribes a force commanded by a British officer. After memoranda and deliberations between the Court and the Ministry of Interior, it was decided to appoint an Iraqi officer to command this force instead of the British officer. The choice fell on the writer of these lines to be commander of this force, and I was appointed assistant to the Camel Corps police in Mosul on 20/2/1922. The Jazira was under the control of the heads of Shammar Al Jarba, and this control extended to the villages of Mosul connected to the Jazira, and included everyone traveling in the Jazira of commercial caravans including sheep taken by merchants to Syria and other trade goods whatever their type. Except that this control does not reach the extent of looting and taking money, but rather money passes safely if the fees decided by the heads of Shammar are paid for it to their specialized owners. These fees are known in the Jazira and among its tribes and those who take the Jazira road as "Al-Khuwwah". Thus the heads of Shammar Al Jarba were spreading their control when the Camel Corps was formed. For the Sheikhs of Shammar Al Muhammad, each one of them is considered a Sheikh, although they respect and obey the Sheikh appointed by the government. For quite some time the Sheikhdom was in the house of Al-Asi, uncle of Aqil Al-Yawar, and the people of this house are nicknamed Al-Jaz'ah after the name of their mother. As for Ajil and his father, they are known as Al-Durrah, the name of their mother also, where the Shammar tribes, especially Al-Kharsa among them, were inclined to Al-Asi. As for the Abda clans, especially those who migrated from Najd to Iraq after the fall of the Emirate of Al Rashid among them, they incline to the new Sheikh, Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar. When Sheikh Aqil was installed as Sheikh, Al-Asi was staying in the Ramilan location inside the Turkish borders near Nusaybin. All Shammar tribes were optimistic about this new event, and the thing they considered a new event was forming a Camel Corps in the Sheikh's encampments with huge allocations they were not accustomed to, because they were content with the fees they took in the name of Al-Khuwwah, and they are

text: 3 - Al Jaffal, and they are famous for guidance, i.e., knowing lands and roads. The most famous man I saw among them is Dhiyab Al-Jaffal, and I accompanied him in some travels. He said to me: Do you want an easy road to walk you in? Or one with trees or one with stones "Radm"? In any case, these slaves were his original force. When the Camel Corps force was formed, these slaves amounted to armed men and became part of the Camel Corps force. After completing the formation of the force, the Jazira became a house of safety, and raiding was completely eliminated. The Camel Corps force from the administrative, disciplinary, training, equipment and armament aspects was under the command of the Camel Corps commander, the assistant police director and his knowledge. As for receiving salaries and distributing them, it was with the knowledge of Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar. This force is considered "Camel Corps Assistance" affiliated to the police director of Mosul Brigade, except that its permanent center is in the dwelling where the Sheikh of Sheikhs of Shammar stays. The center at its formation was in the location called "Ikhdairwat" near the village of Al-Ibrahimiyah belonging to Tal Afar district. The Sheikh and his force used to move from one place to another between this famous archaeological site known as "Al-Hadr" in the Jazira. When the central force was formed in Al-Hadr, the headquarters of the Camel Corps and the Shammar Sheikhdom became in Al-Hadr, until it was moved from there to the police assistance of Mosul district. The Sheikh of Sheikhs of Shammar Aqil Al-Yawar was tall, handsome in appearance and character, beloved, of good reputation before becoming Sheikh. He was successful when he led the raid, and was good in distributing spoils, and this earned him among the tribes, especially among Shammar, a good reputation. As for his luck, as it appeared, he was successful when he led the raid, and appeared with better success when he became Sheikh where complaints accumulate from Shammar's aggressions on the villages of Mosul and travelers to the "District Commissioners" (Qaim Maqams), especially the commissioners of Tal Afar and Sinjar, and to the Governor of Mosul and the British Administrative Inspector, until the matter devolves to referring to the Ministry in Baghdad, and orders are issued to stop paying the allocations of the Sheikh who travels after that to Mosul and confronts the Governor and the Administrative Inspector. The result of this confrontation is the cancellation of orders stopping the payment of allocations. Naturally, this indicates his tact, good conduct in speech, and favor. Thus he was successful throughout his life, may Allah have mercy on him, while he was illiterate, neither reading nor writing, he strove until he learned to sign his signature by hand in writing. The Bedouins, although in their desert far from cities and civilization, understand the situation of the government and rulers and the influence of the English in Iraqi politics. This Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar who refused that the commander of his banner be a British officer, the Bedouins believed that had he not agreed with the English he would not have become a Sheikh, as appears from the poem of the Bedouin poet known as Ibn Dukhi in which he praised Aqil Al-Yawar when he became Sheikh, and said in his praise in the beginning of the poem: I just met the dark one ... A lion following his squadron. O Daham, Aqil became Yawar for us ... From London his rank came to us. Al-Rawi said about Farhan: There is no harm in citing here an interesting story about Farhan Pasha the supreme grandfather of the current Sheikhs of Shammar Al Jarba, indicating to us the entrenched nature of the custom of raiding in the souls of Bedouins in the near generation. The narration says that Farhan Pasha went one day to the village of Al-Mushahada near Al-Kadhimiya "one of the suburbs of Baghdad" and saw its inhabitants of huge bodies, so he asked them: Do you raid? They said: No, for we cannot raid, and we did not take raiding as a craft. So he said to them: Raid those who are weaker (atqa') than you, meaning weaker than you. Hamad Al-Sharabi said praising Al Jarba in the Jazira: My father before me descending for him in a meadow ... And I headed for the destroyers of groups. I found in Sheikh Mandil's notebooks this poem by Manukh Al-Ghuwairi addressing Al-Suwait and defending Al Jarba and its leader Bunayyah, on the occasion of camels taken from Al Jarban: O rider of a free one clapping its hands ... From the offspring of Farhah straight of hands is its foal. As if when it leaned with a step of the fold ... A torrent descended with the edge of a head of a hill. Your destination is Mani' the refuge of the shepherd of the mount ... The old man whose every grey hair is his choice. Taking the cattle is not a disgrace on us ... The shame is with the one dragged over his fire. Seek your forbidden one at the wolf of the squadron ... The sword of Al-Sa'idi engaging in his spine. See your life O Suwaiti is deplorable ... It is no longer worth with you a quarter of a para. The herd is with the squadron of Zawba' ... Throwers of the clothes in the face of the attack. Horses led by your friend Bunayyah ... His answer opposes the riflemen a sign. 5 - Texts of Al-Azzawi in Asha'ir Al-Iraq. Al-Sayih from Shammar: Al-Azzawi said about Al-Sayih: These tribes, this name was not what gathered them, but it is in reality a new name applied to a group of Shammar tribes that had followed Al-Sadid when he fought Al Jarba or disputed with them. So whoever sided with Al-Sadid, or followed him and answered his call was called Al-Sa'ih (The Shouter), and whoever leaned to Al Jarba and followed its heads was counted from Al Jarba. Disputes were ignited between them so they did not want to submit to the demands of Al Jarba while fundamentally Al-Sadid is from them. Examples of that: If you come to Abu Farhan say to him we crossed ... Jazaa'a we do not let the honor be trodden. And if Al-Arwam all ride on our trace ... We must O Safouk shake the head. And we on the war of your ancestors were patient ... It is not from you and coming O wolf of the ropes. Before "Al-Jazira" when "Najd" was our homes ... And our dead in it chase on mares. O Safouk by Allah we do not leave our intoxication Unless "Al-Jazira" is empty there are no people in it. If the belt is a span we measured ... Throwing the armored from old is a base for us. Al Muhammad. Al-Azzawi said about Al Muhammad: I say nothing about them except what Ibn Uthaymir from Al-Tuman said: Whoever argues with them is a lying pretender ... You travel and find in their traces traces. With stabs like flowing streams ... And cheapness of food when it has guards. Another said in a poem praising Faris bin Abdul Karim: The children of Al Muhammad are like the chicks of wolves Or jewels, expensive in prices. Al Jarba. Al-Azzawi said Al Jarba is a nickname that reached them from their mother, and Arabs still use such nicknames. It is said she was afflicted with a "skin disease" so her family left her and moved to another home then she recovered so this name stuck to her. It is the custom of Bedouins to leave the one afflicted with smallpox and similar diseases and move away from him until he recovers or dies to get rid of his infection, and watch him from afar and place for him what he needs of food and drink. Her tribe as is known, is preserved and it is from Al Fudul from Tayy "from Bani Lam". He said: This naming is old going back to their first prince Muhammad by whom they are called, so it is said "Al Muhammad". And this Al Jarba is the mother of Salim bin Muhammad the mentioned which is also preserved but they were not certain of the correctness of its date due to the length of time. These, it is not true what some Arabs used to spread about them that they are from the Sharifs, or from the Barmakids so it stuck in the minds of some of them. Ibn Khaldun transmitted that in his history and denied it. They are from Tayy as Al-Haidari said their kinsmen? From Al Muhammad from Tayy. This is supported by what the author of "Matali' Al-Su'ud" Uthman bin Sanad said, and I heard Bunayyah attributing himself to Tayy the known tribe. The author of "Qalb Jazirat Al-Arab" mentioned that Al Jarba is from the Sinjara tribe, and its branches to Al-Amud and Al Jarba and clarified that from Al Jarba are Al Hariz, Al-Hasana and Al-Buraij. What is transmitted from them is that Sinjara is a Zawba'i tribe going back to Al-Harith from Tayy, and Al Jarba is from Tayy directly and that it is one of their old clans. He said: They are Al Muhammad as preceded, and Muhammad is the head of their lineage column and the oldest known of their ancestors who is still preserved until now. We start defining them from one of their grandfathers Muqrin bin Muhsin bin Mish'al bin Mani' bin Salim bin Muhammad, and it is noted that some names have been swallowed due to the lack of certainty I knew from many of them so they could not memorize perfectly. Mijrin "Muqrin" Ju'airi Al-Zaidan

Taking the rubble carries no weight on us at all… The blame lies upon the one who dragged his fire from above.
Guard your dignity from the wolf of the desert patrol… The Sa‘idi sword is drawn across his backbone.

Your clan’s horses in front of them… He put forth his reply for the scouts to see.

5 – Al-‘Azzawi’s Texts on the Tribes of Iraq

Al-Sayih from Shammar:
Al-‘Azzawi said regarding Al-Sayih: These tribes did not originally have this name that now gathers them. Rather, it is a recent designation applied to a group of Shammar tribes who followed Al-Sdayd when he fought the Al-Jarbaʾ or disputed them. Whoever sided with Al-Sdayd, or followed him and answered his call, was called ‘Al-Sayih,’ and whoever inclined toward Al-Jarbaʾ and followed its leaders was counted from the Al-Jarbaʾ. Hostilities between them were ignited, and they did not want to submit to the demands of Al-Jarbaʾ, especially since Al-Sdayd was originally one of them.

And similar verses to that:

"If you come to Abu Farhan, tell him that we crossed… Jazza‘ah does not allow honor to be trampled.
And even if all the Byzantines ride, we shall track them… We must, O Safuq, cause the nod of the head.
We endured the warfare of your forefathers… It is not from you, O wolf of the spears.
Before ‘Al-Jazirah’ and the days of ‘Najd,’ our land… And our dead roam upon horses within it.
O Safuq, by Allah we shall not abandon your sugarcane… Until ‘Al-Jazirah’ is empty with no people.
If the belt was a span, we stretched it… For long ago we mastered the casting of the mailed warrior."

Al-Muhammad

Al-‘Azzawi said regarding Al-Muhammad:
“I say nothing about them except what Ibn ‘Uthaymir said:

‘From the Tawman, those whom none can dispute except a liar unashamed… They move swiftly, and you find their footprints in the sands.
With thrusts like the flowing blades of spears… And cheap food, for whoever prepares it receives warmth and honor.’

And another said in a poem praising Fāris ibn ‘Abd al-Karīm:

‘The sons of Al-Muhammad are like wolf cubs… Or like jewels, precious in value.’

Al-Jarbaʾ

Al-‘Azzawi said: Al-Jarbaʾ is a nickname that reached them from their mother; the Arabs still call one another by such names. It is said that she had been afflicted with a ‘skin disease,’ so her family abandoned her and migrated to another land. Then she recovered, and the name remained with her. It is common among the Bedouins to leave the one afflicted with smallpox or similar diseases and depart from him until he recovers or dies, to avoid contagion. They observe him from afar and leave for him food and water.

The tribe of their mother, as is well known and preserved, is from Al-Fudul of Tayyʾ—of the Banu Lam.

He said: This designation is ancient, returning to their first leader Muhammad, after whom they are named “Āl Muhammad.” This Al-Jarbaʾ woman is the mother of Salim ibn Muhammad, and this is also confirmed and preserved. The exact date cannot be verified due to the antiquity of the matter.

These people are not, as some Arabs falsely spread, from the Ashraf nor from the Barmakids—claims that stuck in the minds of some, and were transmitted by Ibn Khaldun in his history, but he was mistaken. Rather, they are from Tayyʾ, as Al-Haydari said, their kinsmen from Āl Muhammad of Tayyʾ.

And supporting this is what the author of ‘Matāli‘ al-Su‘ūd,’ ‘Uthman ibn Sand, said: I heard a young man claim lineage to Tayyʾ, the well-known tribe.

And the author of ‘Heart of the Arabian Peninsula’ mentioned that the Al-Jarbaʾ are from the Sanjara tribe, and that their branches include Al-‘Amud and Al-Jarbaʾ. He clarified that from Al-Jarbaʾ are Āl Hariz, the Hasna, and Al-Burayj.

It is said about them that Sanjara is a Zawbi tribe, returning to Al-Harith from Tayyʾ, and that Al-Jarbaʾ are from Tayyʾ directly, and are from its ancient lineages.

He said: They are Āl Muhammad, as mentioned before, and Muhammad is the root of their lineage—one of the earliest known ancestors preserved until now.

We begin describing them from one of their ancestors: Miqrin ibn Muhsin ibn Mish‘al ibn Mani‘ ibn Salim ibn Muhammad. It is noticed that some names disappeared due to the lack of certainty that I learned from many of them, as they were unable to preserve the lineage fully.

Mujarrin ‘Miqrin’ Ju‘ayri Al-Zaydan.

text: 9 - Mutlaq: Known as "Brother of Jawza" and this wanted to make truce with Imam Ibn Saud but his son Muslat did not submit to the Imam's demands of Zakat and cutting the Sha'af "hair of the head" and similar, so he encouraged his father to stand in the face of Ibn Saud so he fought him, and these are the beginnings of their migration to the parts of Iraq and among the motives for leaning towards it. He had shown them his mother who had protruding canine teeth terrible in appearance so he said my father sought the like of this to give birth to the like of me. It is told about him that when Masoud's command strengthened and he ordered cutting the Sha'af and paying Zakat he refrained from speaking with anyone and began watching on a Rajm "hill" staying in it all day and part of the night so they thought he was in love or mentally disturbed so his father sent to him to come to him and obey Ibn Saud's orders so he refused and hit Ibn Saud's slave and bloodied his forehead. Then the father got angry and took his sword and advanced towards him intending to kill him so Muslat said: I climbed the head of the lofty watchtowers ... A tall high cairn standing upright. I groaned a groan that the wolf does not sleep with ... And I feel my ribs from my conscience jumping. I complain to the brother of Jawza cover of the virgins ... The free one from the house of humiliation jumps. If my wishes became like slaves ... And booties in our right hands we prick. text: Al-Azzawi said about Shalash bin Amr: This is known for generosity. He is called "Tal Al-Lahm" (Hill of Meat) referring to what he offers to guests. Because of this leader I mean Faris the thorn of the Ubaid tribe was somewhat broken rather almost erased were it not for the succession of emergence of famous men from Al Shawi helping their tribe Ubaid while these Bedouins have no supporter other than the strength of their arm and their practice in wars and innate intelligence in knowing the political situation of the government so they exploited the situation with knowledge and experience and attained their excellent position with the governors of Baghdad. The government desired to incline a great tribe like this to it and use it against Ubaid and other tribes and it feared their assault and dreaded their power, and it was also in need of knowing what was happening in the Arabian Peninsula and this is what it intended initially then turned to other situations in its time, or that it looked at both matters together and all its hopes were directed to erasing some by some to secure its rule and support its authority and coercion of the residents, so it undertook after that events confirming its intentions and clarifying its situation and all its demands and purposes towards the residents. The first thing the government saw from Faris Al Jarba - besides what was mentioned is what happened in the year 1213 AH 1798 AD - the time of the Governor Salman Pasha the Great for it wanted to entrap Ibn Saud so it gathered all it could of tribal and military force so Faris Al Jarba was with his tribes and so was the Sheikh of Al-Munfaq with those with him of tribes and Muhammad Bey Al-Shawi and many groups the Vizier put them under the command of Ali Pasha Al-Katkhuda except that this one was not knowledgeable in war matters and did not listen to the advice of his senior men from tribal leaders practiced in wars like these especially Al Jarba. The heads of the two tribes mention these incidents generated by politics and exploited the ability from one side to entrap the other, and that is only to spite Al Al-Shawi. But the government did not see from Shammar the results it hoped for so it saw them harder to manage and they were not followers to every order. It came "in Unwan Al-Majd fi Tarikh Najd": That two horsemen caught up with him so when he sensed them or that they called him to duel he pulled the rein of his steed a terrible pull to turn it towards them so the mare raised her head and hands and fell on her back to the ground while he was over her so he became under the saddle and the mare over him so he was caught and killed and his uncle Faris was with him in this battle. As for the effect of this killing of his it was great and had impact in their souls. Among what Ibn Ajaj said in this battle of Al-Munfaq against their first victory over Al Al-Shawi addressing the Sheikh of Al-Munfaq and blaming him for his pride in killing Bunayyah, and he was fleeing from Al Muhammad and a guest at Al-Munfaq, they transmit that he said:

text: You betrayed a Sheikh who always betrays you ... And gave him the rope of the trap. Then you sufficed ninety heads of your people gone for you ... What then O castrator of chickens have you done. In any case his incidents were famous, but the rise of Al Al-Shawi for the second time weakened his resolve so the people rallied against him and he fought until he was killed with support from the government and Al-Munfaq and Anazah. And his uncle was and still is alive and with him in this battle. A period passed until they regained their status in the days of Dawud Pasha and the government sought help from them and other tribes in the war of the Persians in the days of Sheikh Safouk bin Faris and this defeat that befell Bunayyah did not affect the tribes of Shammar but rather it is a duel war and was not a decisive war. Al-Azzawi said about Safouk: This one is more famous than a fire on a flag and the government nicknamed him "Sultan of the Land" in the year 1249 AH - 1835 AD, he succeeded Bunayyah his cousin in his status and gained favor with the government in the days of Dawud Pasha the Vizier. This and records multiplied in his days or that what reached us is more due to the closeness of the era. He is distinguished by practice in wars more than those before him, and important measures in driving the army. It is not denied for the likes of these to excel in the matter of wars having tasted their sweet and bitter and attained the matter from them and got used to them. Sound nature, desert life, leadership, extra practice in the matter of wars, and excessive intelligence, compensate somewhat for technical experiences especially if accompanied by composure, patience on hardships, and attention that might be obtained by a few preserved incidents with practical condition compensating for numerous studies, their cases do not need what is needed in organized wars. If a person is predisposed to love of wars and inclined to them with his totality and his environment helps to undertake their matter always, or observing what compensates for them from chasing game in days of peace, then there speak about bravery and war plans, and correct measures without harm. Had their incidents which they narrate, and the means they take to implement their plans been recorded the matter would be appalling or submission to their competence and ability would occur. It is unfortunate that energies are spent for such matters in raiding each other and every one we see skilled in what he practiced, and the danger and difficulty is in one obtaining his luck from the other. This biography subject is considered in the forefront of Arab braves and their great commanders and had he found a good soil and suitable environment he would have appeared greater. The author of "Al-Matali'" said in the events of the year 1238 AH - 1823 AD about the battle of the Persians which happened in the year 1237 AH - 1822 AD: Several trustworthy people told me that Safouk raided Ibn Al-Shah and crossed Diyala with horsemen from his tribe until he was in sight of Ibn Al-Shah's army so the army's horsemen rode when they saw him and attacked him so he lured them until they crossed Diyala and were far from it so he turned he and those with him from his tribe and from the Romans on them so the Persian horsemen retreated and the horsemen of Shammar followed them and killed those they caught of them and brought their horses and loot. More than one person told me that this is different from the first one mentioned by the Turkish historian. What is preserved in this battle is that it was in participation with the Izzah tribe, and that they performed great performance in it, so they joined hands against their enemy, and relied on themselves, and they had no supporter from the Roman army "Ottoman Turks" and if there were some individuals from Uqayl with them no importance is attached to them. These Shammar in their wars harass the opponent, and make him greedy for victory without decisive victory, until they come to the field of chase and the place of turning - as Ibn Sanad expressed - so they repeat the attack on their enemy, hence they are called people of "The Habit" and so Safouk did in arranging his plan and their success and they are more accustomed to it and fundamentally from his youth he practices it. The detail of the battle is in "History of Iraq between Two Occupations". Ibn Sanad praised this battle of his with the Persians and his support for the Vizier and clarified that he was the army commander and with him the tribes until he said and when Safouk supported this Vizier he granted him Anah and what follows it of villages so he attained his status with the Vizier so he opposed his enemies and allied with his allies. As for Safouk's generosity proverbs were struck with it and proverbs acknowledged it. Safouk has famous incidents with Anazah tribes most famous of which: 1 - Day of Basala. It is a day Shammar won over Anazah in the year 1238 AH - 1823 AD. 2 - In the following year Anazah won over them which is the year 1249 AH - 1824 AD. In this last battle Shammar was broken so the Vizier strengthened the arm of their elder Safouk.

In any case Shammar's break this time was not the decisive one but rather it is according to the custom of Arabs in their saying "War is buckets (turns)". Therefore the government did not leave them, but rather took their hand so they regained their first status and undertook its war missions with opposing tribes. The government had from the tribes what serves as an army ready for emergencies and present for struggle and mobilization. Safouk's other incidents are of this type. Among them is what relates to the Shammar tribes but the incident of the year 1249 AH - 1831 AD indicates that he remained loyal to Dawud Pasha the Vizier and hated the government of Ali Rida Pasha so he did not submit to him. That is because the Governor of Mosul Yahya Pasha was also of the opinion of Sheikh Safouk Al-Faris and there was correspondence between them. He urged Safouk to rise so he opposed the government and managed to cut the road between Baghdad and Mosul and began roaming between the two rivers so he gathered a large force and came near Imam Musa Al-Kadhim so he fought Ali Rida Pasha the Governor and the government army and his hope is great to punish the force in front of him and seize Baghdad so this incident had a great impact on the government's soul, and in the result of this war Sheikh Safouk was forced to withdraw and leave the heavy loads. When the government learned of the intentions of the Governor of Mosul it removed him and appointed in his place Sa'id Pasha the former Governor who was in Baghdad. The government after this battle of Safouk with Ali Rida Pasha Al-Lazim tricked him and arrested him and banished him to Istanbul and with him his son Farhan Pasha who was young and learned Turkish during his father's stay there, and the period he spent was three years. Among the strange things told about him is that he came to the Sultan through the mediation of Sharif Abdul Muttalib so he entered upon him and then began looking right and left. This is what called for the Sultan to get angry at him again and expel him from his presence and he did not know the reason while he was hoping he would honor him. That is because of what the Sultan saw from him of bad manners, so the Sultan thought of him and did not know he was a Bedouin, and his likes do not know the ceremonies of honors, and the government fundamentally does not know the traditions of Arabs and their customs so it is not strange from the Sultan to believe in him what he believed while he is far from Bedouinism, and not accustomed to roaming nor national tours at least, nor does he have in his hand books of tribes to enlighten him about their conditions. We have seen from the late King Faisal great patience with the harshness of tribes and their roughness as he hears all their Hawsa (war chants) and receives them with all breadth of chest and comfort, because he is knowledgeable of them and the varieties of their natures and conditions. Then the Sharif mediated for him a second time to enter so the Sultan agreed, but when he came to the Grand Vizier he began advising him to observe appropriate ceremonies and not to raise his gaze nor turn to his sides, so he said: I will not enter, and there is no benefit for me from that entry and then I prefer staying because I will go to my tribes and tell them that I saw the Sultan and saw his court and what is in it of such and such, and if I told them: I came out as I entered and did not look at anything then they would not believe me but lie to me and say: We do not believe that you entered. So news of that reached the Sultan so he was pleased with what he narrated, and allowed him to enter and the Sultan permitted him to see him and to look at other places and ministries "Wizarat" and all the wonderful buildings and grand palaces and antiquities. The Sultan pardoned him, and he tested the situation on one hand, and on the other that his tribe is accustomed to raiding and looting and it is not possible to determine which of the two reasons called for his rising against the government again in the time of the Governor Najib Pasha and it is said this time the government did not declare chasing him but rather took the path of peace and trickery to arrest him and sent to him the famous tribal heads to bring him closer to reconciliation and submission and obedience. So they brought him as obedient, peaceful to it and submissive, when he reached Hor Aqarqouf and approached Baghdad Muhammad Bey drew his sword on him and struck him killing him treacherously and unaware. Sheikh Safouk had spent most of his days in wars so he is practiced in them, does not rest without them, and his stories are like the stories of ancient heroes and their wars, and Shammar's councils are not free at a time from memories of his valor, and singing of his feats and virtues of his courage. Today the house of general leadership over Shammar is in "Al Safouk". It was said Safouk's killing was at the hands of the Turks in the mentioned way in the year 1840 - 1841 AD as came in the book "Tribes of Syria" and it has a view [reservation], because his incidents with Ali Rida Pasha are after this date as you saw. text: And his son Faris lived also peaceful to the government and observing its side and he is Sheikh of Shammar in the parts of Syria, holder of a high position there, and among those who gathered qualities of manhood and cunning and memorizing past incidents and the relationship of other tribes to them but he always wishes to show the superiority of his tribe over other tribes. Al-Azzawi said about Faris bin Safouk: He is the son of Safouk and father of Mish'al Pasha, Ali Bey former Governor of Trabzon and Director of Public Debts had come on an official tour to Baghdad recorded in his book named "Siyahat Zurnali" written in Turkish and printed in the year 1314 AH - 1897 AD he had written it as a journey about the year 1300 AH - 1883 AD to the year 1304 AH - 1887 AD clarifying what he saw on his way from Istanbul to Baghdad then India he said: "I have gone to meet Sheikh Faris Al Jarba - after his passing in Mardin - so his son Muhammad received us" and this Muhammad is not his son but the son of his brother Abdul Karim "and entered us into his tent, which is of hair and its length is from 60 to 70 cubits and its width from 25 to 30 and has many pillars and is very huge. He described their houses, food, coffee, and council but the people did not talk in demands to alert to them except that he said: And in Sheikh Faris's council were about 60 leaders. He said: There was not among the Arabs there what calls for honoring and ceremonies for standing and sitting, so we did not see standing among them, and it appears that the referred tourist did not know that the one sitting with him there is no one greater than him to stand for him. Naturally modesty takes over his council especially that they saw a stranger at their Sheikh's or in the correct expression their Emir. He said: Some of them were engaging in drinking Narghile, and voices among them rise and they all speak together so clamor increases in their association "freedom is not known among Bedouins nor the extent of leaders' authority and that it is limited except by right" then he had lunch and described the Mansaf presented to him and that the Sheikh was inviting groups after others to eat until little of it remained so he called the boys and these entered the same Mansaf and ate in it because their hands do not reach it due to its hugeness, and when he saw the Mansaf and its hugeness and that it is filled with rice and meat he was taken by confusion and began looking at his companion's face as if pointing to its hugeness. He said: That Sheikh Faris we insisted on him so he refused to eat with us and said thus we are accustomed even that among what called for their confusion is that he remained standing throughout their sitting for eating and remained serving them himself as is the custom of Arabs with the dear guest. But when he saw the insistence occurring from him he called those who eat with him from those present about "7 or 8" he said they ate with us with the five [fingers]!. Then he says: And after we bid farewell and went returning from at evening his son "his nephew" Muhammad came to us and presented to us a horse, and we had presented to him a rifle, and since we had honored him with the rifle we accepted this gift of his with thanks. End summarized. This is the father of Sheikh Mish'al Pasha. From the saying of this Turkish tourist and what he saw of Sheikh Faris's insistence and presenting food to him and honoring him with an Arabian horse, and describing his station you know the place of other Shammar Sheikhs. Sheikh Faris has - besides Mish'al Pasha - sons Mulhim, Muslat and Al-Humaidi. Al-Azzawi said about Faisal bin Farhan: I have seen him repeatedly and he is still strong although advanced in age, and this one I could not know from him more than raiding incidents, so if I exceeded for you he says to me ask Aqil "Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar his nephew" and his stories about raiding were delicious and refreshing. Sheikh of Al-Rub'iyyin in Iraq Mubarrad bin Suki uncle of Faisal used to say: He is above what he narrates. The strangest thing I heard from him is the story of the wild boar that wanted to kill his brother Abdul Aziz father of Sheikh Aqil, and they were young so he went to help him and save him but he fell with him in a predicament so he could not get rid of it and his brother did not dare to help him, that is because he grabbed his tail from a side so he could not let him go out of fear of him and began turning with him so he could not escape, then Abdul Aziz managed this boar so he hit him with a shot with a Shotgun "called with us Fard and it is a type of gunpowder rifle except that it is small like a pistol and contains only one shot mostly and is placed in the person's belt or in a special holster like the pistol holster without difference" As for his raids and news in his wars these are very many, and the most important in them is what he got from them of suffering, wounds, capture or defeat. And his state recites: So I returned to Fahm and was not returning ... And how many like it I left while it whistles.

text: Al-Azzawi said about Aqil: He is today the Sheikh of Sheikhs of Shammar in Iraq, and son of Abdul Aziz Ibn Farhan Pasha, and most of my information about Shammar tribes I quoted from him directly by mediation and from Mubarrad bin Suqi and some famous Shammar Sheikhs who are relied upon. I saw him a logical man, wise, perfect, good in association from every aspect, and I contacted him much, so I did not find what bores from him but rather there is gentleness of side, politeness of morals, goodness of logic, strength of expression, and truthfulness of tone, and the pen is unable to mention all his merits, and the summary of what I can say is that he combines noble Arab qualities. I do not forget his conversations about tribes and their custom and his direction of some Bedouin incidents and rulings which I did not find with others, and is not found with most knowledgeable ones I saw. We did not find important incidents about his other children except that Abdul Razzaq had a battle with the Turks and as for Farhan and Faris their relationship with the Ottoman government was very good, and they obtained the rank of "Pasha", and enabled what their ancestors attained of authority and influence over their tribes so their fame covered the rest of other Shammar heads, so we do not prolong the saying by mentioning their branches. Al-Azzawi said: Shammar tribes used to roam in the Arabian Peninsula and Mesopotamia without opposer or contender except what happens due to disagreement of tribes with each other or with the government sometimes. After the occupation of Iraq by the British army in the year 1917 AD and Syria by the French army each team of Shammar became independent in its side and leadership was entrusted to an Iraqi in the Iraqi Kingdom and to a Syrian in the Syrian Kingdom. This leadership was not its sole reason and there is a leadership from each of Al Muhammad over a district or tribe or several tribes, so authority is divided by the multiplication of Al Muhammad and their plurality and in the time of the Ottoman government one of them is known, and if he is not fit to manage tribes the clans incline to whom they desire from Al Muhammad and the leader remains the medium of understanding. As for today everyone knew a leader in his side. The leadership of Shammar in Iraq was decided to Sheikh Aqil Al-Yawar. He is today the Sheikh of their Sheikhs no contender rivals him in it, and he succeeded Daham Al Al-Hadi who went to Syria, and now he is on the borders and leads "Shammar of the Borders" as the French authority named them. And Mish'al Pasha became Sheikh over Shammar Al-Zour "so the Syrian government named them" and they are Shammar who inhabit Deir ez-Zor. And there are other Shammar led by Mithqal Al-Ajami "so in Tribes of Syria" and the French government names them "Shammar Demir Qabu". Here it is noted that rivalry exists between Aqil Al-Yawar and Daham Al-Hadi his cousin but nothing occurred between these two leaders what the French authorities expected due to enmity or predicted of occurrence of what stirs latent hatred and malice and that they will remain enemies all their lives deducing from the apparent reconciliation incidents that occurred during the year 1926 AD in Anah and the year 1929 in Hasija. This does not exceed intuitive matters thought to be realized or that the distance of disagreement tensions between sections of a strong tribe whose assault and authority is feared if it agreed and its word united due to momentary quarrel occurring between two relatives not leading to more than forming personal enmity so it leaves no room for Shammar to confront each other. In any case - as we said previously and say - the choice of leadership in Bedouins is only for talents they see in individuals of the leadership house. Al-Azzawi said: Those we counted the Emirate used to transfer to them. The houses of these tribes in winter are tents woven from goat hair which are Mazalim (shades) and each Mazallah of them is composed of three or four or five Shiqaq "Shakak" according to ability and the width of each Shiqqah is a cubit and a third or half a cubit say: a meter and its length about twenty-something to thirty cubits so they join the edge of one Shiqqah to the edge of the other and men sew it and their tents in summer are from Shiqaq of Shawb Al-Uwayn or Cowpea. The meaning of Shawb is that they take the branches of Al-Uwayn and its stems after its leaves yellow and soak them, in water for a period of seven or eight days then lift them from it and sew them with sticks and clubs and pound them with woods and stones a severe pounding until they become like cotton and this pounded [material] is called by them Shawb, then women start spinning and weaving it into Shiqaq, then men sew it into a tent raising it with poles as a roof for the house. Some reliable verified Sheikhs of Shammar Tuqah narrated, while I was sitting in their presence saying: Before five or six backs i.e. generations we were on the western side of the Tigris with Shammar Al Jarba the Bedouins, a single bond gathered us and our looting does not cut from Mosul and Shirqat to Souq Al-Sheikh and Qurnah and for matters that occurred to our ancestors they turned backs on each other - i.e. separated - so our ancestors crossed from the western crossing of Tigris to its eastern crossing so a bitch of ours from our dogs lagged behind in the western crossing and her name was Tuqah so a woman of ours started lifting her saying Tuqah! Tuqah! Tuqah! So the Bedouins Shammar Al Jarba named our ancestors Shammar Tuqah, insulting and belittling them and this name continued on us to this our day so we became two tribes or factions and we have numerous clans. Qasim Al-Dujaili tracked him saying: Then he counted from Shammar Tuqah "Al-Gharir..Al-Zaqarit..Al-Aqra'..Al-Sa'id ... Al-Zawba'" and the correct is Zawba' "Al-Su'ud". As for Al-Gharir, Al-Haidari said about them the text: Al-Gharir are from Himyar and among their tribes are Al Shahwan and Al Bakr. As for Al-Zaqarit they are from Abda, from the children of a man named "Zaqrut" with Fatha on Zaa and his brothers Al-Afarit and Al-Ja'far and others, and Al-Qazwini mentioned them in his treatise saying: "Al-Zaqarit is a tribe of Arabs in Iraq attributed to Shammar Dhu Al-Janah from Lahi'ah Al-Himyari father of the Shammar tribe". Then Al-Dujaili said rectifying his article: We had written lines regarding Bunayyah Ibn Qurainis or Qurainis or Quraynis Al Jarba and said that he is from Shammar Tuqah and our belief was so and last month we went to visit His Excellency Sayyid Mahmoud Effendi Al-Naqib in Baghdad so we met Sheikh Mijwel bin Farhan Al Jarba one of the Sheikhs of western Shammar, and Haj Abbas Al-Ali the elder of the people of Kut, and when we settled sitting we began exchanging conversation as is the custom of visitor and visited and after a while Sayyid Mahmoud Effendi said: You mentioned that Bunayyah is from Shammar Tuqah and the correct is that he is from western Shammar. Then he turned to the mentioned Sheikh Mijwel and said: Is not what I say correct? text: About the events of Sha'ban year 1330 AH, Al-Arab magazine said: Ibn Muhaid, head of Al-Fid'an, raided Shammar, descending in the parts of Mosul, and looted from them 300 camels all belonging to Faisal bin Farhan Pasha and returned to his lands safe. It said about this history: Ibn Muhaid, leader of Al-Fid'an and Anazah tribes, drew Shammar tribes to descend in the Jazira, and marched with his tribes and crossed the Euphrates river and passed Anah and Rawa heading to Shammar in the parts of Mosul. And it came in the magazine "Lughat Al-Arab" in the events of the end of the year 1329 AH about Humaidi bin Farhan: The Wilayah of Baghdad appointed Humaidi Bey bin Farhan Al Jarba as Sheikh of the Shammar tribe instead of his brother Mijwel, whose inability to maintain security in his lands became clear. When Mijwel heard that, he ordered some tribes of his followers known as "Al-Mathluthah" "and the meaning of Al-Mathluthah to them is mixtures of people from separate tribes" to alert and rob everyone who opposes them on their way and some of that happened especially on the road of Baghdad and Samarra. And in the events of 1928 AD Lughat Al-Arab magazine said: The government of Sham intends to make the presidency of Shammar tribes by election to know the measure of reliance of those tribes on which of the two Sheikhs: and the two Sheikhs are Daham Al-Hadi and Mish'al Al-Faris. And in the events of the year 1930 AD it said: His Excellency Sheikh Mish'al Al-Faris head of Shammar tribes in Syria came to our capital and he had taken refuge in Iraq two months ago and he is consulting our government to settle his tribes in Iraq. And in the events of 1927 AD "Lughat Al-Arab" magazine said: It is narrated that Sheikh Daham Al-Hadi and Sheikh Mish'al Al-Faris finished collecting Al-Wadi "camels tax" from Shammar tribes occupying the lands of Syria so Sheikh Daham collected the Wadi of "Al-Kharsa" tribe and Sheikh Mish'al Al-Faris collected the Wadi of "Al-Thabit" and "Al-Fadaghah" from "Sinjara" tribe with the Wadi of "Al-Amud" tribe. And about the month of Ramadan year 1330 AH "Lughat Al-Arab" said: More than a year ago a dispute occurred between Sheikh Aday Al Jarban and Rashid Al-Dabbuni, because the government gave Sheikh Aday the lands of Al-Ghubayshiyah from the annexes of Al-Bughaila and Al-Jazira to farm, so Rashid tried to take it from his hand but did not succeed and Rashid was killed, then Nazim Pasha returned Aday to his lands and settled him in them, but the judiciary sentenced Aday and his tribe in absentia so they are now asking mercy from the government to pardon them asking mercy from the government to pardon them. And it said about the events of the end of the year 1330 AH: Shammar tribes marched with their horses and camels from Mosul to Iraq under the presidency of Sheikh Humaidi Bey and camped at Ain Al-Arnab at a distance of two days west of Baghdad. Their number is estimated at two thousand horsemen heavily armed. They are awaiting the order of Prince Ibn Al-Rashid to join him and act by his counsel "from Al-Riyadh": The more correct is that they came for provisions (Imtiyar). And about the month of Muharram year 1331 AH it said: The Shammar tribe crossed Baghdad and Mesopotamia, led by their supreme head Humaidi Bey bin Farhan Pasha, heading to the district of Al-Jazira then Kut Al-Imara and from there to the brigade of Al-Munfaq, for the fertility of its pasture and cheapness of living in it, and with them Al-Qusait also head of the second division. 1
